Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6443, file 880-25, part 2)
SIR:

I beg to report that I duly cleared the operation charges in connection with the Sardis Indian Preventorium, for the month of September, 1941, and under date of October 4th, submitted Form I.A.181, attached to Agency Voucher No. 463, for $401.69, in favour of the New Westminster Indian Agency Trust Account.

The gross per diem costs were $1.29 per capita,

Statements for the charges of the month, together with the receipted bills from the various firms, are enclosed, in duplicate, for your information, and records.

The cheque in refund of these expenses has not yet been received, and I shall be obliged if you will look into the matter, as I will have no funds with which to meet the October expenses.

Your obedient servant,

Enclosure.

A.O.N. Daunt,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

December 15, 1905

To the Honorable the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs Ottawa,

Honorable Sir—

The Indians of Stuart's Lake District have forwarded me the enclosed petition for an Industrial School for their District. They request me to forward the same to you as it is to your honorable person that they address themselves.

Knowing these Indians well, I can assure you that an Industrial School would be the best means to help these Indians.

They are probably amongst the poorest of any Indians in worldly goods, and they depend on the Government to come to their aid both for the building and for the maintenance of their children at school.

As they are all Catholics, they appeal to me to intercede for them in their efforts.
to secure what they ask.

I have no hesitation to join them; for I am convinced that they are in real earnest, and that they will make as good a case, as any Indians have ever made of the opportunities that shall be afforded them when a school shall be given them.

The only kind of a school that shall be of real benefit to them is an industrial school, and the distance at which they are from convenient shipping points supplies will be so expensive that it would be useless to think of any other grant as sufficient except an industrial school.

Grant—

Sir,

Referring to your letter of Sept 21.

Having regard to the establishment of Indian Schools in this Agency I beg to report that in some sections of the district the outlook is apparently good. At Stony Creek with a population of 181, and at least 30 children of school age the prospects are perhaps best. I held a meeting there last Sunday and discussed the whole question with them, explaining what the Department was willing to do and what not, and they expressed themselves as very anxious that a day school should be established there. The Indians were evidently very much in earnest, as to try them I said "Now the building and maintaining of a school here will cost the Board a lot of money, would you be prepared to do anything to assist the work?" and they replied that if the Board would supply grub they would cut and haul logs for the building.—It would be cheaper of course to contract the work, I merely cite the incident as tending to show their good faith.

However in a case of this kind calling as it does for considerable expenditure of money, one has to consider well the fickle nature of the Indians—claiming for a new thing and if not to his liking casting it aside. Although they ask for schools they do not realize the...
advantages of them. Then their religion is to be considered, they are all Catholics and their Spiritual adviser, Father Crooks is uncompromisingly opposed to Day School and how much he may use his influence to kill the project and how far he may be successful are problematical. Schools under religious control might probably give best results, but to encourage another denomination to take hold simply means that before it could succeed the little grain of faith the Indians now have would have to be destroyed. If the Department could be assured of always securing the services of devoted men to teach, men with infinite patience and tact, although without scholastic attainments, building influences could be overcome. I would say, go ahead success is a right, but I know such teachers are difficult to obtain. The Provincial Board paid a little school at Stuart Lake for a few years and although paying a salary of $95 a month they had three teachers in four years only one being willing to undertake a second term. This school with the consent of all parties admitted some Indian children to make up the desired number. There I am informed the Priest took away and sent to the Williams Lake Industrial school, compelling the little one at Stuart Lake to close down.

The School question is a hard nut to crack.
and this report may seem very pessimistic, but I do not regard this as final; I would simply advise the Department to go slow as the whole thing is in the nature of an experiment.

Leaving out the question of expense, and from the standpoint of actual teaching results to be obtained, also taking into consideration the nomadic habit of the Indians, the lack of influence of many of them together with the strong opposition before mentioned which the Bay Labor may have to contend against, I have no hesitation in saying that an Industrial boarding school on the lines of Williams Lake school would give good results; but the cost of establishing and maintaining same would be staggering. The Department's decision not to extend this system is I take it final and probably wise.

I shall be glad to give the department any further information at my disposal, but would advise no hasty expenditure of money until absolutely assured of the cooperation of the Indians, and the entire elimination of unfair opposing influences, and I would suggest that no definite action be taken until next Summer, when Inspector M'Donald may visit the Agency, and I can have a chance to confer with him on the subject, the Department could then have the advantage of a report from him as well.

In the event of a school being established at
Stony Creek I believe it would possible to obtain the services of a suitable teacher here. Dear Sir:

Having just returned from my visit to the Indians of the interior of B.C. from Hazelton to Fort George, I hasten, according to my promise, to communicate to you the results of my observations with regard to providing these 2000 Indians with the blessings of a suitable education.

1) I was glad to realise that the parents are all anxious to send their children to school. They are perfectly willing to part with them during the period necessary to their education. There are over 200 children of school age.

2) The conditions these Indians live in are such that I have no hesitation in affirming that the Department cannot do them justice, at least so far as education is concerned, without a good boarding school; as without more than one half of the children would be completely deprived of school facilities. In fact there would be pupils enough to fill up two boarding schools. One could be located at Taylorville or close by, the other around Fraser Lake. Both places are centrally located, on the CPR and adapted to the purpose intended.

3) As the needs are urgent one boarding school ought to be erected next year. There are some sawmills in the Bulkley valley which sell lumber just as cheap in Prince Rupert. During the
mean time, however, viz. whilst waiting for the completion of a proper school I would be glad to see some teachers appointed in the principal centres; they might be of some benefit, especially to the adult population.

4) Although not connected with education I beg to mention again the question of the Hagwelget reserve which I am afraid might become a bone of contention between the Indians of Hazelton and of Hagwelget on account of the clerical error that has crept in title name of the reserve; as it appears, the whole reserve comes under the name of ((Hazelton indian reserve)). The considerable value which the Hagwelget side is acquiring on account of its proximity to the Taylorville townsite, might become the source of the annoyance. Could not that question be settled once for all?

May, I would say, could not a revision of some reserves be effected? Some are very large and others very small. The Hagwelget reserve is much too small for the number living on it. They figure that within two years their supply of fuel will be completely exhausted.

5) Finally, I must bring to your notice the advisability of having the Hagwelget and Morice-Town reserve surveyed in lots of moderate size, which would be given one by one to the natives in proportion as they cultivate them. That would prevent some over-ambitious ones from fencing & taking more land than they can make use of; thereby, leaving others without even a garden plot.

Yours very respectfully,

E.M. Burns

Hay and other wild grasses grow so prolifically that it is considered there would be no difficulty experienced with barley, rye, oats, wheat, etc. At Stuart Lake, as noted in last year's report, all the garden vegetables and root crops have been grown successfully, as have the small fruits, such as raspberries, currants, strawberries, etc., both at the Hudson's Bay Company's post and at the Roman Catholic Mission, a mile farther up the lake, at which latter place barley, rye and oats were seen growing and almost ripe, with fine full heads.

During the winter, as ascertained from the Indians, the snowfall is light, and although sometimes the glass drops very low as a rule the weather is not very severe. Dear Sir,

Permit me to bring to your attention a matter which is very dear to my heart and which is of the utmost importance to the welfare of many in this section of the country. I mean the matter of extending the benefit of schools to the natives of Bulkley Valley and to those in the immediate vicinity of Lake Babine, in this Province.

There are a great many natives on the upper part of the Skeena River and tributaries but at present chiefly concerned with the tribe called Thene, living in the aforesaid districts of the Babine Agency. They number about 250 in the Bulkley Valley and about 350 around Lake Babine. All of these people are living in permanent settlements and those residing in the Bulkley Valley earn their living by teaming, packing and raising horses and cattle; only very few follow hunting as a profession. The occupation of the people around Babine Lake is pretty nearly the same but for the fewer chances given them to pack and freight in winter time; therefore they follow more hunting and packing during that season.

So far these people have only come into contact with the white man during the last few years and have had very little chance of getting a school education.

On different occasions the Rev. Father E.M. Munoz the prefect of this ecclesiastical district of the Catholic Church, and the Rev. Father N. Cocoola have applied to your Department for the establishment of a school for the Babine District, but in view of the high prices of handsawn lumber, the Department thought it advisable to wait.
At Haggulghet Village I started a little school with thirty-eight children from this village alone. I have kept it open for two seasons, but as it handicapped me seriously in the exercise of my other duties as parish priest of a large district, I had to give it up, of which decision I notified the Indian Agent in consequence. During all this time the following principals became clearer to me than ever before.

1. A day school in an Indian settlement is of very limited use among the aborigines. The good inculcated in the school is very easily forgotten when so many contrary influences after school hours are active to drag the children back into the old rut. Only a boarding school can prevent those disadvantages and can accomplish lasting good results.

2. Moreover a day school is insufficient because many of the children are too poor to attend school regularly, having to assist their parents in procuring a livelihood for the family. An empty stomach is a hard thing to stand for before feeding the mind the body must be fed; therefore, only an institution that gives them food and clothing can achieve the desired results.

All those who have been working among the aborigines for any length of time will endorse these principals which I have cited above. The Rev. Father N. Coccolis who has a practical experience of thirty years hard work among the natives of British Columbia, is a most ardent advocate of this system.

Now, dear Sir, we have about seventy children of a school age in the Bulkley Valley and about the same number in the Babine district which would certainly furnish the material for such a school, with regard to which I might point out that there are many other places where the Government has granted Indian boarding and industrial schools for a far smaller number of children.

If this school were granted it would be the first of the kind given to the natives of this part of the country,
the central north of British Columbia.

The natives themselves are absolutely in favour of a school, nay are clamoring for it. They have come sufficiently into contact with the white population along business lines to realize the necessity of it. Moreover the delay in granting a school certainly exposes the Government to criticism, as many of the settlers have come from various parts of Canada and of the United States where the natives have been given the opportunities of enjoying the benefit of good schools. I am persuaded that there is no tribe more eager to take advantage of them than the Thene tribe.

All the natives before mentioned have been christianized by the Catholic Church and are practical Christians, therefore any school granted by the Department should not be denominational but should be a Catholic school in accordance with the policy of the Department as carried out with regard to the Industrial School at Cranbrook, the St. Mary's Mission on the Fraser River and the Industrial School at Qu'Appelle. We can easily and quickly arrange with some religious sisterhood of the Catholic Church to undertake the teaching part of the institution.

Only a school of this character will be suitable for or congenial to the natives and I am quite sure that it will be the only one to give satisfaction.

These are, dear Sir, a few points regarding the need and constitution of a school in this neighborhood which I beg to submit for your information, in the hope that they will receive favourable consideration of the Department.

Trusting that I may be advised of the decision which will be made by the Department on this, for the Thene Indians, most important matter, I beg to remain,

Yours respectfully,

Rev. Father A. Godfrey, O.M.I.

Dear Sir:

The acknowledgment of the Aelin Indians' right to a school and the generous support of the said school a few years ago, was the good work of the administration of which you, Sir, are the head. As I was the founder and manager of the said school, I had several opportunities to deal with your important Department.

The fair treatment I have then received was not the least encouragement that led me to assume the task of building and directing a boarding school at Fort St James, B.C.

It is in behalf of this last institution that I am addressing you these lines.

Much to my surprise, Mr. McTlen, Indian Agent for this district, advises me that the Department wants the Stuart Lake Indian Day school to be closed immediately after the Boarding school has been started.

If such a plan were immediately followed I could not do justice to all pupils, nor would I economize any of the Department's money.
To do justice to all pupils, both boys and girls, must have their own apartments for class, and manual labour, for eating, sleeping, recreation etc. This would require a very spacious building, and during these war-times, (The Government having declined to actually fulfil its pledge of erecting here such spacious building, that might cost $50,000.) the ecclesiastical authorities have done the next best thing. According to means and time we have erected a school which is not sufficiently large to fully accommodate both sexes.

Therefore I beg to you, Sir, to allow me to keep open the Stuart Lake Day school for girls, while boys will all attend the Boarding school, for Indian parents are more eager even to have their girls than their boys educated.

To attempt to accommodate both boys and girls in the actual building, would, I am afraid, not only compromise the success of the work, but instead of lessening expenses it would increase them. For instance twenty girl boarders would cost a good deal more to the Department than the small teachers salary of $800- a year and the small amount expended for fuel and lunch. This lunch to the day-school pupils will be even less expensive owing to the fact that no boys shall share in it. So both the pupils and the Departments interest will, I am convinced, be better served for the time being by keeping open the Stuart Lake Day school, for some time, along with the new boarding school of the same place.
May I hope, dear Sir, that after you have weighed
the justice of my demand you shall see your way through in
granting it.

Feb. 15th 1919

The Indian Boarding School at Stuart Lake

To W. J. McAllan

Sir,

Several years ago the government pledged itself to erect a Boarding School in the Stuart Lake District. Over 200 children of school age justified the existence of this school.

The erection of such school was postponed till the spring of the G.T.R.R.R.

But as the spring of the said R.R. company during the great war, the government decided to delay again the erection of the school till after the war.

The war was over for two years and no sign of its end was in sight. Hence the authorities of the church being granted Government support for the maintenance of the school, decided to erect a temporary building to start the education of as many as could be accommodated.

Such a building erected for a temporary purpose cannot be considered adequate to the need of such an institution, as the following description will make evident.
I. Location

The actual school is situated 35 feet from the road leading from the Indian town to the store. Hence the daily transit of people who interfere with the pupils when out in recreation, and who are also tempted to make too many visits.

II. Insufficient Space

The school comprises three buildings. The first erected several years ago for a half school was built on a small area of cleared land, the only land then available. Hence its location on said side. It is made of sound logs chinked every fall with either mud or lime and straw. The Indians who built this house put the bottom log on the ground, wherefore it is fast getting rotten and will soon become a menace to the inmates.

The size of this building is 40x50 without ceiling. The only two-class rooms of the school are in this building. One is 21x25 and the other 21x14, to accommodate 73 pupils. These rooms are about twice too small for the number of pupils on hand, much less would they accommodate the hundred pupils actually deprived of any education for want of space in the actual school.
Beckless to say that the Indians' builder did not put in any facility for ventilation and that therefore before the class hour is over a faint heavy cloud of foul air rests on the heads of both teachers and pupils. Such is the state of Class rooms built for a temporary object. Such also is the state of all other rooms of the temporary school.

The boys' bed room is in the attic of the log house and is 35 x 70. It is occupied by 60, with a guardian girl bed, a wash stand, a stove, and a stair way. But as the floor, the chimney and the stair way are in the middle of the room they occupy so much space that eight tiers had to be hung on the walls and that hardly a foot space is left between the beds, whilst the guardian's bed is surrounded with shelves filled in with clothes.

The girls' bed room is 28 x 31 and 10 ft ceiling. Add another room 15 x 31 and 7 ft ceiling. This last room had to be discarded during the fall for want of air space. But as the first room is also occupied by guardian girl bed, stove and wash stand, it is too small to accommodate everyone so that there are still 10 girls sleeping in the small attic.

The staff room 25 x 10 is on the same floor at
the girls bed-room, but a stair way and a store are cutting so much into it that really it may be said that the staff is sheltered until the staircase.

A small room 13x22 is all the recreation hall at the disposition of the girls, and yet this space is also burdened by a stairway. The same limited space must be said to exist in the girls and boys dining rooms and all other rooms of the house. Such fact there are still further reasons calling for a new building.

There is no sick room. A small office room 10x12, the only office in the house adjacent to the boys recreation hall has to be used for a sick room, and the office removed into a cabin in the Indian town.

The staff has no parlor, no community room and is actually under a dark store room 12x12 for both purposes. To reach said room, visitors have to pass through the girls recreation hall, so do also the boys going to their dining room.

In a word there is lack of room and inadequate space in existing rooms.

But to make one understand the crying need of a new building one needs only to see the 12 stoves and their frequently leaking stove pipes dripping food on floor, beds,
are tables. What a fuel bill for so many stoves.

What danger of fire with so many stove pipes especially in a temporary building in which walls and ceiling are all too much kindling.

On connection with a new building, a water system must be provided for the carrying of water from the lake with buckets to free from giving satisfaction. Must be steady flow would be the thing for kitchen use and washing and bathing purposes. Indoor outdoor toilets should also be provided at least for the staff, sick purposes and general night use. Outdoor toilets in hot time may be for all pupils.

The new building can be erected at short sale with advantage. Blue clay hills close by the school can be turned into bricks. A mountain of lime stone is two miles from the school. Sand and gravel are plentiful on the lake shore. A saw mill also two miles from the school can provide most of the lumber needed at a reasonable figure.

Twenty acres of land are under cultivation near the school and sixty acres of will half land are four miles off. Several tons of hay taken from different other meadows could be bought as bail at five dollars a ton to feed 21 heads of cattle and 4 horses.
As most of the pupils do to be from near Stuart Lake. Since the natives are used to the school being in their camp, since also they are deriving great benefits from the institute by providing it with fish, meat, vegetables, labor etc. And since the intense land clearing and farming has given a new impulse in the same direction to the natives and has served as an inducement to white settlers who desire to cultivate the beautiful agricultural land on the lake shore. I believe the new school should be erected on the same locality to facilitate the recruiting of pupils and to continue helping the steady growth of this district by both the whites and the natives.

Yours sincerely,

J. Clark
Principal

Dear Sir,

Your letter of the 31st ult. announcing that the school at Fraser Lake may not be voted this year and not even next year came to me as a bolt from the blue. I never expected that the Canadian Government would thus delay the fulfilling of their part in a bilateral contract when the Indians have fulfilled theirs ten years ago. I so far depended upon the justice of the case but begin to lose hope and confidence.

However as I am writing to the Hon. Minister of the Interior, I wish to inform the Department that the excessive cost of material and labor cannot be used as a pretext for the delay. For at Fraser Lake, sand and gravel are found right on the spot, seasoned lumber is obtainable at reasonable price at not distant saw mills where piles of lumber are waiting for a market, labor both skilled and unskilled can be secured in that place at a living wage which is lower than in large centres, a siding to the railway track would enable to unload cars on the premises. I think that the few materials that would be above cost next Summer could not amount to much.

I must state moreover that the buildings at Stuart's Lake were not intended for such a long period of time. If the new school is not immediately voted they must be improved both for the sake of the teachers and the pupils. And a government grant will be required for these necessary improvements as I have already bled myself white for that school and I can do nothing more.

Respectfully yours,

Memorandum

Mr. Scott,

The Stuart Lake Boarding School is now being carried on in temporary buildings in the Indian Village near Stuart Lake, and at a point distant about fifty miles from the railway. The buildings erected are very temporary in character. The larger or boys' building being of logs and the two adjoining buildings of frame construction which provides very congested and inadequate accommodation for the pupils enrolled.

The construction being inferior and the buildings heated with stoves, it is necessarily cold, and owing to the construction cannot very well be remedied.

From the arrangement as shown on the plans, I am of the opinion that improvements cannot be economically made to the building to provide better accommodation, except that additional temporary space might be added to the girls' building providing better housing facilities in that portion.

The present site is undoubtedly well situated for farming purposes, but, fifty miles distant from railway, by roads over which all supplies, etc., must be transported by teams at a great cost, and for this reason, it would appear undesirable as a site for a school, unless a satisfactory site near to the railway could not be obtained, as the long and difficult haulage would not only materially increase the cost of the building, but would be a permanent and constant expense in the transportation of the supplies.

The
The erection of a school in this remote district will be very costly, and with the limited appropriation available at this time, that provided will, undoubtedly, be expended in such manner as to ensure the greatest benefit, and as double the accommodation equally necessary can be provided at a more easily accessible distance and at the same cost, it would appear advisable to expend the money available where the greater benefit would accrue.

In the meantime, it should be definitely determined if a more advantageous site for the Stuart Lake Boarding School could not be obtained, providing adequate water supply and sanitary sewage disposal system, near railway communication, so as to lessen the cost of erecting these buildings and the subsequent additional cost of carrying on the school.

A temporary addition 25' x 33' to the girls' building, costing about $5000.00, will provide a work-room, recreation-room and dormitory which is very much needed to relieve the over-crowding there, and enable the school to do its work under better conditions, and provided funds be available, I would recommend for your consideration that this expenditure be made.

Architect.
Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of Mar 21st No 285754 re respective merits of Stuart Lake, Fraser Lake or other point as site for proposed new school for Stuart Lake Agency.

In reply I beg to state that I favour its location on Se-as-bunkut Reserve (No 4) on the south side of Fraser Lake about midway between the stations of Fraser Lake and Encombe. Advantages of this location may be summarised as follows: The G.T.P. Railway runs through the reserve and as stated in the fifth paragraph of your letter, if a siding were put in care of building material etc could be unloaded right on the spot and I think it might easily be arranged with the railway people (Govt. road now) to stop passenger trains at any time when there were children or other passengers for the School aboard.

The reserve contains 506 acres with only two Indian families resident so that 300 acres could easily be appropriated for School lands. Soil is of excellent quality, is mostly timbered with growth of poplar willow and some spruce, but small open parky spots occur. Ten to twenty acres could easily be got under cultivation the first year without much expense in clearing. Water could be pumped from Fraser Lake or perhaps a well could be sunk. Building site and drainage good. Consult the Agency map and you will notice this point is not far removed from its geographical centre.

The Reserve is under the jurisdiction of the Department which I think is important.

In considering Stuart Lake as a location
Its main disadvantage is its distance from the railroad—40 miles which means that on all supplies for the school and on all construction material not obtainable at Stuart Lake there would be an extra cost of from one to two cents per lb.

The location of the present school is on land belonging to the R.C.Mission and is the best site in the neighbourhood unless land for the purpose could be obtained from the Hudsons Bay Co. whose land adjoins the Mission property.

The observation of Principal Allard in the fourth paragraph that the most of the pupils are located in the vicinity of Stuart Lake can only be considered correct as referring to the pupils presently at school as naturally those living nearest the school were chosen. Also Father Allard says "Bricks, lime, lumber etc can be obtained". Well lime can be burned and rough lumber has been cut but no bricks have ever been made or has any planed lumber yet been turned out at Stuart Lake.

It is also very unhandy getting children from distant parts of the Agency to Stuart Lake as they have to be met at Vanderhoof and conveyed by teams the rest of the journey.

Noonla Reserve two miles west of Vanderhoof or the southern part of Nautley No 1 reserve three miles west of Ft Fraser might also be considered as possible locations but in my opinion none have as many advantages as No4 reserve mentioned on first page of this letter.

Will be pleased to furnish any other information desired if in my power.

Right Reverend Sir,

In further reference to Your Lordship's letter of the 8th of February last, requesting that the erection of a new boarding school building to meet the educational requirements of the Indian children of the Stuart Lake Agency be undertaken at an early date, I beg to inform you that before any definite action can be taken, the selection of a suitable location for such a building will have to be carefully considered and the site decided upon.

In selecting a site the following points should be carefully considered, namely, the quantity and quality of the land with a view to future farming operations; an adequate and easily obtainable supply of water for domestic and fire protection purposes; good drainage facilities; a central point for obtaining pupils for the future carrying on of the school, it not being desirable, owing to the cost involved, to transport the children long distances to and from their homes. The question, too, of obtaining the material required for the erection of the building and the transportation of the same and the obtaining of the necessary labour; also, after the school is erected, the future cost involved in the transportation of supplies should be considered.

Mr. Agent McAllan was requested, having the above requirements in view, to report fully on the merits of the respective localities suggested, namely, that mentioned by Your Lordship at Fraser Lake, also, the site recommended by Rev. Father Allard on the location of the present school at Stuart Lake. The agent reports that he is strongly in favour of the location of the proposed new school building on Se-as-bunkut Reserve, No. 4, on the south side of Fraser Lake about midway between the station of Encombe and Encombe. The advantage of this location is

him as follows:- The G. T. P. Railway runs through the reserve and if a siding were put in, cars of building material could be unloaded right on the spot and it might be easily arranged with the railway authorities to have passenger trains stop at any time when there were children or other passengers for the school. The reserve contains 506 acres with only two Indian families residing thereon, so that 300 acres could easily be appropriated for the purposes of the school. The soil is of excellent quality and 10 to 20 acres could easily be got under cultivation the first year without much expense in clearing. Water could be pumped from Fraser Lake or a well could be sunk. There is a good site for the building with good drainage. The reserve is in the centre of the agency and sufficient children could be obtained for the present and future requirements of the school.

As a large expenditure will necessarily be incurred by the Government in the erection of the building, it should be located on a site under the ownership of the Department. The locality recommended by Agent McAllan would appear to meet all the present and future requirements, not only in the erection of the new building but as well in the future carrying on of the school.

In considering Stuart Lake as a location the main disadvantage is the distance from the railway which means that all the supplies and all construction material not obtainable at that point, there would be a heavy cost for transportation, also, in future, the cost of freighting of supplies would place a heavy burden on the management. About the middle of March, 1922, with the authorization of the Principal, the Rev. Father J. Allard, I started a Cadet Corps at the Fraser Lake Indian Industrial School. In forming this Corps I had several things in view. In the first place I wanted to develop in these boys some notions of patriotism, some feeling of pride in belonging to the British Empire. In the second place I knew how greatly these boys need the physical drill which is an important part of the cadet drill. Also I had it from my own experience when at college and from the experience of other teachers in B.C., how great a help the cadet drill is in giving the boys the habit of discipline, in teaching them to obey immediately and without murmuring. This Cadet Corps has given good results already. As witness I may give the copy of a clipping from a Victoria newspaper, which I enclose and in which Mr. Cairns, Chief Inspector of Indian Agencies, who inspected this school, is kind enough to speak in complimentary terms of this Cadet Corps. Now, Mr. McAllan, I am confronted by a rather trying situation. To keep up a cadet Corps takes money. Especially in the beginning the expenses are rather heavy, as the first year lots of things have to be bought, as uniforms, caps, etc. As far as uniforms are concerned, the Inspector of Cadet Services at Victoria was kind enough to send me 45 uniforms, part-worn ones; but you know how small in size are the boys in the school, and these uniforms can not be altered enough to be made fitting for the smaller pupils. With great trouble Mrs. Ockoniy has altered about twenty of these uniforms, which will fit 20 cadets, but the rest of the 59 cadets have none. This means that uniforms have to be bought for the rest of the cadets, 39 in number. The Militia Department allows $1.25 for each cadet who is in a military uniform at the annual inspection. I could not buy the uniforms before I receive the money and I can not get the money before I get the uniforms. I was therefore turning in a vicious circle from which I got out by simply buying 36 khaki shirts, military pattern, at my own expenses. Then again, caps had to be bought. These caps cost about $1.10 each. You see what there will be left when I get the allowance, there will be nothing left but a debt. I had to pay $18.50 for express charges prepaid by the Ordnance Department on uniforms and belts, a matter of courtesy, and therefore billing. The uniforms which are too big now can of course be used in the winter time over the other uniforms, but that does not help me now. Then, I have to buy cleaning material, green cloth for facings, a Union Jack for the Corps etc. In short, Mr. McAllan, I shall find myself confronted by quite a deficit at the end of this year. I may get an allowance of about $100.00 for myself, but as I shall have to buy a uniform and have been unable to locate a second-hand one, I shall have to buy a new one, and that will take more than my allowance.

Dear Sir:

Herewith I beg to submit the report of the Fraser Lake Residential School for the quarter ending March 31st 1928.

The health of the pupils has been generally good, though we had to deplore the death of one of our boys, 12 years of age, victim of pneumonia.

The progress in the class room is remarkable, of course this is the best quarter for it, as the winter roads and cold weather keep the parents away from the institution.

Besides the feeding of the stock and the hauling of fuel not much work was done on the outside by the boys. The girls are kept busy making stockings, dresses and mending. 203 dresses, 191 aprons, 296 drawers, 201 chemises, 500 pairs socks were made during the year.

The improvements of the year are the removing of the eave troughs from the roof to prevent the ice from forming along the walls and backing the water under the shingles. The extension of the electric light to the barn and other outside buildings.

The installation of the refrigerator plant at the cost of $2320.00 for which the Department allowed $1600.00. The plant besides keeping the meats and other articles in good condition during the summer months was storing in the fall 30 carcasses of beef and 22 of pork butchered at their best and keeping the Institution with splendid meats even to this date.

The acquisition of a truck for the sum of $875.00 and a tractor for $1100.00. This last implement proved very useful in breaking new land paved with heavy roots.

Farm and garden returns amounted to the value of $2750.00. Cattle and pigs butchered gave meat valued $1200.00. Butter and cheese made on the farm were estimated at $275.00 eggs at $400.00.

Considering the long duration of the winters and the cost of feed in this part of the district we found that it is not advisable to have a large stock.

We have at present 74 head of cattle and two teams.

Hoping that these remarks may be of interest

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

With the quarterly reports ending December 31st instant, no doubt you would like to have statistics pertaining to our institution.

First I must say that during the quarter the health of the pupils was generally good. The epidemic of colds or hooping-cough prevalent in the district, consequence of sudden and frequent changes of weather, visited our school, but prompt attention, isolation and care given to the sufferers prevented the spreading of the disease and though many children died of it in the surrounding villages we had only one death in the school.

Mr. Cairns, school inspector, coming on the 4th of October and spending three days here, seemed pleased with the work in the classroom though the children had just returned from their vacation.

Many improvements took place on the farm. Dear Sir,

Hereewith I respectfully submit the last quarterly reports for the year ending March 31, 1929.

The health of the pupils, on the whole, has been very good with the exception of the Measles, which visited us in the fall. The measles hit us hard, as many as fifty-five pupils were in bed at one time, giving the staff a rather busy time for a period of six or seven weeks. Two pupils fell victims, both were boys. One of sub normal vitality could not resist the progress of the disease, the other succumbed to tubercular pneumonia following the measles.

Krysepsia, Pneumonia and eye sores were legacies left from the measles. By medical attention and careful nursing we are now almost rid of these and we count ourselves fortunate at having only had two cases to report.

Our Class-work has been very satisfactory. No only has gratifying results been achieved in the various classes but the interest taken by the pupils has been unprecedented. Altogether this part of the work has been most encouraging.

Outside the classroom the boys show much interest in agriculture, stock raising, farm implements and up to date machinery have a special attraction for them. Blacksmithing and garage work also make a special appeal to them, and now with the advent of carpentry and cabinet work our manual training hive much promise for the future. Besides the above our boys get considerable experience in butchering, cleaning & quartering boves and hogs and preserving fish and meat.

The girls besides Crocheting, Knitting & embroidering do all kind of plain & fancy sewing. Their work was exhibited at Vancouver and many prizes were captured. They made during the year 5 dozen of night gowns, 3 dozen chemises and drawers, 7 dozen stockings, 8 dozen dresses, 9 of aprons, 12 of pillow cases &c.

Improvements to buildings & farm have kept well apace. A Silo has been erected, the carpenter shop completed, the farmers house plastered and electric light installed in all outside buildings.

The Department presented the school with pure bred Holstein stock One Bull, prize winner at Victoria and two heifers from which good returns are expected. A new Safe has been installed, a new cream separator added to the dairy equipment, a valuable team of young horses purchased for the farm as well as potatoes Digger and Ensilage cutter. The farm has received a good deal of attention, about 15 acres of new land has been broken and the old land greatly improved. A conservative estimate of farm produces for the year gives us $4134.00 this amount comes from beef, pork, butter, eggs, cheese and honey all raised on the farm. The land yielded a fair crop.

Hoping that these remarks will be of interest to you and the Dept.

Yours truly,

Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 22nd No. 163-1-I re milking cows I have to say that this is taught not only to the boys but also to the senior girls.

The care of the cow before, during or after milking, to insure clean healthy milk, is imparted by one who has visited and studied the methods in vogue in some of the best dairy farms in the country.

Respectfully submitted,

I submit the reports of our School for the quarter ending June 30, 1929.

Health
The health has been very good, only one case of Symptomatic Purpura with several hemorrhages caused us much anxiety. The boy affected by it has after a month of special treatment and nursing entirely recovered. Some cases of sore eye and ear were or are looked after. An oculist visiting the School was kind enough to test the eyes of those with defective vision and prescribe for them. The pupils were all vaccinated and the dentist attended to the needs of all.

Classroom
The majority of the pupils show ambition for progress by the attention given to the teachers in the four classes and their efforts to grasp what they are taught in the different branches.

Manual Work
The boys helped in seeding fields and garden. Under the direction of the Manual Instructor they built an addition to the calf barn, erected chicken fences and new outside toilets in the play grounds of boys and girls.

The girls are kept busy with housework, making and mending clothes. Laundry and Dairy work are included in the program for the girls.

The closing exercises of the school will take place on the 15th of the following month, some of the pupils are going to their parents and many are to remain with us for the holidays.

Yours truly,

H. Coccollo O.M.I.
Principal

Dear Sir,

I submit the reports of our school for the quarter ending March 31, 1930.

Health

The health of the pupils has been generally good.

We had to register two cases of Pneumonia which promptly attended had no sad consequence, also one case of Purpura and one of Chorea. These two last cases were sent home at the request of the parents. For the last three weeks the mumps invaded the school, but nothing to alarm.

Class Room

There is marked progress among the old pupils, they love their books and are anxious to learn, but many of the new comers seem to have horror of the English language.

Manual training department

Good work is done there. The boys not only learn the handling of tools but they have made many useful articles for the house, and with their instructor have built this year a silo, dairy, piggery, large shed for farm implements, and an addition to the calf barn. We see by their letters to their parents the interest they take in manual training.

Farm

Much attention is given to farm and stock as it is seen by the return which consisted: From farm and garden in grain, roots and hay $4,590.00
From stock, beef, pork, eggs and butter $1,636.23

Improvements

During the financial year the improvements consist in the finishing of the silo, erection of a dairy, floor in the play shed, new outside toilets, implement shed, piggery, addition to the calf barn.

Repairs

Radiators, New and large boiler for the laundry. New implement potato cutter and planter. New binder and mower. Installation of Electric fire alarm apparatus.

Dear Sir:

Herewith I beg to submit the reports of our school for the quarter ending Sept. 30, 1930.

The majority of the pupils faithfully returned after the holiday expired on Aug. 15, but for some we had to go or send after them. As soon as the parents see their children industrious and well trained they insist on keeping them at home.

Health:
The general health is good. Those who show little weak have a special food and the nurse does not spare cod liver oil and other tonics. All have been successfully vaccinated. Two girls died at home during the holidays, probably of pneumonia.

Our boys take interest in farming making use of the many farm implements to which we add every year to give an opportunity of becoming familiar with them. We put in the hands of the big boys the publications received from the Department of Agriculture and other magazines on same subject.

The hours spent in Manual training under the direction of the Instructor are well employed making useful articles. We understand the necessity for our pupils to have a practical education besides the work done in class room.

The girls presented many pieces of needle work, much admired by the public at the Fort Fraser Exhibition and carried number of first prizes.

The constant cold weather during spring and greatest part of summer followed by very hot days without rain prevented germination and consequently garden and farm returns were poor. We have already ordered two cars of potatoes and five of hay, as there is nothing to buy in the district.

The moving of the hot water jacket to a new location built on purpose eliminate danger of fire and explosion, giving satisfaction.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

Herewith I beg to submit the report of our School for the quarter ending June 30, 1930.

HEALTH - Two boys, one 12 years of age and the other of 9 died after ten days of sickness, of which the doctor could not find the symptoms. It was only after they had passed away that the other boys told that they had seen them with hemlock in their hands. One girl also of 14 died of hemorrhage of the lungs. Outside of that the pupils enjoyed good health and are lively and happy.

The pupils of the 8 grade are well prepared for entrance examination, but considering that they would have to go where such examinations are taking place and also that the parents would not consent to their children to go outside of the district we did not attempt to present them.

The boys with the farmer and gardener have seeded or planted the hundred and twenty acres of the cultivated land, but the cold nights and even days with the prolonged drought are retarding the growth.

The girls are kept busy, as usual in needle work and housekeeping.

Vaccination.

This month all the children not yet vaccinated were done so by the Doctor.

In consideration of the restless dispositions of the pupils after seeing the white children out for the holidays we decided to close our own school on the first of the coming month.

Hoping that the above will give you an insight of our work,

Yours truly,

Rev. N. Coccola, O.M.I.

Sir:

Permit me to submit the annual report of our school ending March 31, 1931.

HEALTH

Up to the middle of November the pupils enjoyed splendid health when at that time the Influenza raging in the district broke out in the School. We had 56 cases and three died of it in spite of the attendance of the doctor and the good care of the Sister nurse. The rest are all well now and look healthier than ever.

We took advantage of a specialist calling on us, to have the eyes, ears and throats of the pupils examined. Nine of them found with faulty vision have been fitted with glasses and treatment procured for the others.

CLASSROOM WORK

Boys and girls are progressing in all grades, showing more ambition than in the past.

MANUAL WORK

The boys in manual training, under the direction of their Instructor have made during the year many useful articles for the house: desks, cupboards, dressers & much admired by the visitors.

In the farm they have been assisting at the seeding and harvesting. Their work in the blacksmith shop mending sleighs and farm implements is a proof of their skill. The assistant to the engineer is trustful and attentive to his work.

The girls besides the housework have made this year 224 dresses, 165 petticoats, 380 aprons, 80 pairs of stockings, 80 nightgowns, 64 drawers, 75 shirts. They are skillful with the needle and in fancy work have carried out many prizes at the exhibits.

IMPROVEMENTS DURING THE YEAR

A press was installed in the laundry, wire fence erected around the piggyery and girls playground. The hot water jacket was removed from the engineer room where it was too close to a gasoline pump and placed in a space built between the house and the laundry, bought a tinsmith outfit to instruct the boys in that line, connected the hot water tank with the kitchen range, a canopy was fixed above the kitchen range, bought a feed grinder for the stock. 10 acres of new land have been cleared and fenced ready for seeding.

FARM PRODUCE

On account of the cold spring and drought in summer, crops were light in the district. To provide for the stock we had to buy five carloads of hay, which considering the scarcity and freight came high. From our fields we got 40 tons of mixed hay, 30 tons of sunflower green oats and peas for the silo, 66 bushels wheat, 400 bu. oats, 50 bu. barley, cabbages 1000 heads, roots 1 tons. Beef, pork, eggs, butter to the value of $3,628.24 Total of Farm produces $5,302.20

Hope that this report will be of some interest to you,

Your obedient servant,

Rev. N. Coccola, O.M.I.,
Principal

Sir:

The re-opening of the school was fixed to the 25th of August and on the 16th the first truck from Stuart Lake brought in a good contingent. September 10th, 1931.

Sir:

I have received a written request from the Rev. N. Coccolo, regarding changing the name of the Fraser Lake Indian Residential School, to "Indian Residential School, Lejac, B.C." in other words to drop the name Fraser Lake altogether. The Principal gives as his reason for making the request the fact that their mail often goes astray or rather goes to Fraser Lake Post Office some five or six miles farther along the Lake, as there is only a tri-weekly mail service up here it often means that the mail is considerably delayed as it has to be returned by the Post Master at Fraser Lake to Lejac. (Lejac is the name of the railway siding at the School property and there is a Post Office right on the School grounds known as Lejac).

I can quite easily understand how mistakes of that kind can be made which will cause delays and often times serious inconveniences to the Principal, but I also appreciate the fact that the Department must have some distinguishing name for the School, so I would like to recommend that the present name of the School be changed and that the School be known in future as; "THE STUART LAKE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL" at Lejac, B.C. This will give the school the same name as the Agency and might be the means of avoiding delays in the mail service as well as in Express packages. Trusting to hear from the Department in this connection at your convenience.

Your obedient servant:

H.H. Moore,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I am also aware of the very high esteem he is held by all creeds and classes in the community, whites and Indians alike, and I am very anxious that either he or some other such Father be appointed and with as little delay as possible, for it is essential that it be done before any of the Spring work is started.

Dear Bishop Bunoz:

At the time of Your Lordship's visit in November, last, you will remember discussing the matter of the retirement of Rev. N. Coccolia, O.M.I., on account of age, from the principalship of the Lejac Indian Residential School. While the Reverend Father has devoted many years' of faithful service to Indian work, it is felt, from the point of view of continued efficiency in the management of this school, that a change in principal should be arranged before the spring work begins. I understand that Father Coccolia, who, to all appearance, is still active and keeps the school in fairly satisfactory condition, insofar as the inside work is concerned, is too far advanced in years to keep in touch with the farm work, with the result that he has to depend almost entirely on hired help. Consequently, the school is not getting the maximum returns from the farm and the stock.

I would request that the matter of a change in the principalship receive Your Lordship's consideration, and that you will arrange to nominate a fully qualified principal to succeed Reverend Father Coccolia at your early convenience.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir:

HEALTH:
The pupils' health has been very good. One case of glandular troubles and another of Tuberculosis were sent home with the hope that entire rest and outdoor life would be beneficial to them. Little sore eyes and ears promptly and constantly attended were cured without having recourse to the doctor.

Work in the classrooms is very satisfactory with the new method of teaching with the new books suggested by the inspector, making the study interesting and easy for the pupils.

The boys on the farm and garden have been helping in the seeding and planting, but the changeable weather with very little rain is far from being favorable to the growth.

Under the manual training instructor many useful articles have been made, besides the many repairs in the buildings.

The parents asking to have their children for the first of July we decided to have the closing exercises on the 28th of June. The holidays to last until the 15th of August. Dear Sir:

Herewith I have to submit the reports of our School for the quarter ending Dec. 31, 1931.

Health

The health of the pupils has been generally good, we had some cases of mumps and lately two of pneumonia among the boys. One of them is now entirely well and the other is recovering gradually. The Doctor is very attentive and comes when called.

Classroom work

The school was inspected on the 22nd and 23rd of October and the Inspector was pleased with the general standing.

Improvements

Referring to your letter of the 14th, S-2 re New Name for our School I desire to have it known: Father Lejac was an Oblate priest and the first to have a residence in this part of the Province.

Dear Sir:

Herewith I beg to submit my report of the Lejac Residential School for the quarter ended Mar. 31, 1933.

HEALTH:
With the exception of one case of Tubercular Meningitis, the general health of the children has been exceptionally good. We have been very fortunate, considering the amount of grippe and influenza prevalent in the district, to have had only three or four children in bed and those only for a day or two due to the necessary care being given immediately.

The doctor does not hold out any hope for the girl with Meningitis but all that can be done for her is accomplished. Her father, on notification, visited her and was quite resigned to what may be the outcome of her illness.

Dr. G. G. Welsh, eye specialist, visited the school and examined the eyes of all the children finding 15 cases of Trachoma. Following his instructions we are treating them at the school.

CLASSWORK:
The children are showing marked progress in their class work and a keener interest is evidenced by the number advanced at the beginning of the new year. The children who were entered with the new term are doing especially well and are very ambitious in their studies.

MANUAL TRAINING:
The children engaged in Manual work show and adaptness to their duties. The bigger boys have given splendid results in the making of desks, waste paper baskets, and other pieces of household furniture, while the younger boys are fast learning how to handle the tools in order to replace the lags to be discharged. The other boys are kept busy tending to the stock and doing other outside chores.

The girls are busy with their many household duties and much comment can be made upon their fancy work, knitting, embroidery etc.

GENERAL REMARKS:
Farm work is given thoughtful consideration. After much experimentation it has been found that Alfalfa does the best of any feed crop with the result that 5 acres were sown 5 years ago. Two years ago another 7 acres were put in. This year we are sowing another 12 acres of the crop while 10 acres are under Sweet clover acting as a nurse crop for more Alfalfa.

As a further experiment 4 acres of Brome Grass and Western Rye were planted last year and from appearances in the fall it will do very well.

Our plum and apple trees produced fruit last fall which resulted in us ordering a further supply to be planted in the spring.

3300 pounds of fertilizer are on order which we feel assured will greatly benefit the soil.

The seed for the coming spring will soon arrive so that spring work can be promptly attended to.

Our cattle are attracting the attention of the residents of the district to the extent that we have managed to find sale for 4 of our Holsteins.

The supply of beef stock was sufficient each year to keep the school supplied with meat. About 25 head of calves and 20 pigs were butchered for our needs.

The chickens, which breed we have been able to keep, have kept up a steady surplus of eggs.

Very respectfully,

[Signature]

Sir;

I am taking pleasure in writing you from my new field of labor. After leaving Fort Chipewyan and the other missions of the Mackenzie District where I have been working for 14 years, I am now acting as Adjutant Bishop to Bishop Macoe in Northern British Columbia and the Yukon Territory. In this capacity I established my winter quarters at the Indian Industrial School of Lejac, confided to our care.

In regard to our residence here, allow me to approach Your Department concerning a plan I have in mind, as a result of the survey I made of the conditions of living of our missionaries here as well as in the surrounding district.

1. I found it very inconvenient for Father Principal as well as for the other priests connected with the work at the School not to have any separate living-quarters outside of the School building proper.

2. My presence here is the occasion of more numerous visitors coming from the surrounding mission district; much to my regret I feel quite unable to give them an appropriate hospitality in the very restricted quarters set apart for us in the School.

3. As Fraser Lake is the most central place of meeting for all our missionaries working among the Catholic Indians of northern British Columbia, it is my most earnest desire to have a large residence established here, wherein occasionally I could gather all the priests of the region interested in Indian work for their annual Retreat and Convention.

In consideration of the above stated reasons, I beg to ask you whether it would be possible for the Department to sell or to lease to the Oblates of Mary Immaculate for an indefinite period of time a portion of the land owned by the School, so that we might build, at our own expense, within a reasonable distance of the Indian School, the projected residence, which would be used both by the Personnel attached to the School and by the other missionaries of the district.

I would suggest as the most suitable location for our Residence the portion of the School property located east of the School building and extending down the bank as far as the C.M.H.R. track. The said piece of land can be easily made independent from the rest of the School Property; would have an outlet to the station; and would mean no practical loss to the Department.

Dear Sir:

Herewith, I beg to submit a report of the Lejac Residential School as to date ending Dec. 31, 1935.

HEALTH

With the beginning of the quarter, the health of the children was at high ebb with a very few minor illnesses such as colds, etc.; and although the respective reservations in the community were affected with measles we fought a losing fight to keep the school immune to the disease by not allowing visitors from any of the affected camps. On Nov. 16th, we received our first introduction to the epidemic when two boys were ordered to bed having contracted the measles in some manner unknown to us. From that time on one child after another became laid up with the disease until about 70 per cent of the pupils were in bed at one time. From then on the disease slackened until at the present time we are fortunate in having a very few in bed convalescing from the after-effects.

No casualties can be blamed directly on the measles, though we much regret the passing of one pupil, Euphrosia Louie, who passed away Nov. 20th, after being a pupil in the school for only 4 months. From the time of her admittance she was under observation due to an advanced tubercular condition and then, when she contracted measles, the odds were too much for her frail spirit to combat. Other indispositions are of a minor nature and receiving careful attention are mending rapidly.

CLASSROOMS:

Work in the classrooms had been progressing in very good order but with the development of measles many children were inadvertently detained from attending sessions with the unfortunate result that the studies were compelled to lag somewhat.

Naturally, the work set out by the curriculum to be covered by Christmas cannot be completed; but with resuming of full class again every effort is being made by the teaching staff to bring their respective grades up to the standard.

What work has been covered has been done in a thorough and conscientious manner both by the teachers and by the pupils.
MANUAL TRAINING:

Manual Training activities are again in progress with practical knowledge again the keynote of its studies. The boys are finding their work both interesting and helpful with a decided change in their attitudes towards their tasks. With the privileges of outlining and planning their work they feel the responsibility attached thereto and endeavor to perform their tasks with care and precision.

A very noteworthy benefit derived from the system of "Practical Training" is the manner in which the children are taught and shown how to utilize odds and ends which otherwise would have been a waste of material. Competition is a feature in the success of the system which will bear out lasting proof to the advisability of its introduction.

The young ladies are as usual well stocked with duties to perform. Their household tasks of darning, knitting, sewing, etc., always abound in plenty so that their time is well spent in caring for their own and the boys garments.

The neatness and alacrity with which their tasks are performed have often been praised but not without just cause.

The girls may also be highly commended for the advancement made in the cooking department where every advantage is allowed them to learn the deeper secrets of the culinary art.

GENERAL REMARKS:

With winter with us again, work in the fields and other outside points has ceased. Work is proceeding, however, along other lines in preparation for requirements for spring. The season is now admirable for procuring the necessary materials for fence repairs and additions to same with the fact following that the men are kept constantly employed getting out the timber needed.

We are greatly pleased with the information recently received to the effect that our requests for a new root cellar and piggery have met with the satisfaction of the Department and grants for same will be allowed so that erections can commence as soon as the weather conditions will permit.

Estimates show that a required expenditure of between £2500 and £3000 will be necessary to cover costs of both buildings but this will give us added storage for our garden produce and also additional room for hogs in the piggery. The present iron from the burned hogsty can be straightened and re-used but a new pen will have to be added to care for our increasing stock.

At the request of Mr. Melan, whose visit during the summer proved so beneficial to us, we are again making an appeal in behalf of the children's playhalls. These quarters are in extremely poor condition and some aid is necessary in order to put them into a shape suitable for recreation halls. In poor weather it is impossible to keep the youngsters outdoors while the dust arising from the concrete floors and collecting in poorly constructed clothes presses makes the playhalls unbearable as well as impairing the health of the little ones.
This matter has on several occasions been referred to the Department and although Departmental visitors have acknowledged the necessity of some measure being taken nothing has ever been accomplished. The question has been taken up with many authorities on floors and it is the advice of these gentlemen that a good grade of Battleship Linoleum be used to combat the scourge.

We trust that the Department will take an interest in the foregoing request and give it some serious consideration.

The school has lately been extremely fortunate in procuring a large variety of reading material for the children. The books were obtained from the Anyox Community League at a very nominal sum covering freight and other slight expenses. In this manner we hoped to acquaint the children with a wider range of wholesome and interesting literature. The children are making splendid use of the opportunity and becoming well acquainted with the various authors.

Farm returns for the past quarter have been very satisfactory and although during the winter months it is harder to keep up the summer standard we, nevertheless, are making every endeavor to continue the good record.

In closing I wish to express my appreciation to the Department for the many favors extended to us and in return assure the strict co-operation of the institution at all times.

Respectfully submitted,

L. H. Rivet, O. M. I.
Principal

Dear Sir:

Allow me to draw your attention to your letter of May 3rd., 1934 file No. S-2-587 re an increase of pupilage at the Lejac School.

As the time is nearing the completion of the fiscal year, I feel that the attention of the Department should be drawn to their promise of increased appropriations.

At the present time the school is housing, at its own expense, a number of pupils over the allotted number. Other children, who should be receiving the schooling are remaining at home. Requests have been made for their entrance into the school but due to the heavy expense involved we have had to refuse them. The school is capable of housing 175 children and if the Department is in accord with our wishes there is no reason why more children should not be allowed the privileges afforded by the institution.

I wish also to bring to the notice of the Department, the matter of a new root cellar for which, last April 17th. we asked a grant.

At the present time we have not sufficient storage capacity for our vegetable crop even though after the Department's refusal to our request we did not produce the quantity intended.

Unless some help is forthcoming this year we will again next year have to harvest a small crop which means that extra necessities will have to be purchased as required and space allows.

With the means of production with which the School is so well fitted, such steps appear advisable. I feel certain that in submitting their year's estimates for 1935-36 the Department will meet with no difficulty in procuring the necessary funds for a new root-cellar.

Since the construction of the School and buildings some 12 years previous, they have never received a second coating of paint and the result of battling the weather conditions are very evident from all angles. Every building, including the school roof, is very much in need of refreshing up and should receive the immediate attention of the Department so that the work may be commenced as early as possible in the New Year.

It is estimated that 100 gallons of paint would be required to complete the work and I trust that the Department will give their consideration.

Frustrating that you will outline our needs clearly and give your assistance, I am,

Very truly yours,

Signed:- L.H.Rivet, O.M.I.,
Principal.

Sir:

Allow me to draw your attention to a few facts relating to our school, which when given serious consideration, I feel certain will receive rectifying from the part of the Department.

Of which the Department is aware, when taking over the principalship a year and a half ago, the school status was at a very low ebb. Farm production was extremely limited and repairs were necessary to machinery and buildings. The need to receive immediate attention and by fortifying the positions with capable hands we, today, can boast of improvements which will please within the limelight and satisfaction of the Department.

However, the necessitated improvements involved heavy expenditures and with the meagre income from the per capita grant it is impossible for the school to continue its improvements which still remain undone.

With the rendering of the fiscal year report for March 1934, a request was made for increased pupilage. At the time, Departmental estimates had already been submitted and our request was acknowledged with a promise of increased pupilage for 1935.

At the present time we are housing over the school's quota in terms of sustenance and many parents are asking admittance for their children but due to lack of funds we have had to refuse. Inasmuch as the building is capable of caring for a larger number and the children are plentiful in the different camps, it is rather unfortunate that some means cannot be undertaken to hire them to secure the education they so sorely require. With some of the conditions existing on the reserves, it is almost inhuman to leave the children amidst such surroundings; but with the present financial difficulties to face it is impossible to accept them into the institution.

Nevertheless, I feel that the Department will not fall short of its promise and that next spring we may have a remedy for such conditions.

Secondly, allow me to again submit our cause for a new root cellar or which the school is very badly in need. In former years it was customary to purchase all the required sustenance for the school. Last year, I made a very determined effort to produce our own needs and had my efforts...
crowned with success inasmuch as our gardens and hay fields produced abundantly and sufficiently. For the first year in the school's history we have not had to buy feed for our stock. Forty-five extra acres of land are ready for cultivation next year; but again like this year, we will have to limit our garden produce unless some means are arranged for storage.

It does not seem creditable to such an institution, which should in reality act as a model farm to the district to have to be dependent upon the energies of other farmers to cope with the needs which it should be producing for itself. This fact has many times been commented upon by visitors in very emphatic terms and in justice to the Department the school management feels that the school should be the model the people expect.

With present shortage of store-room facilities it is an impossibility for the school to come with such a situation and for that reason, unless the Department sees fit to carry the burden of constructing a new root cellar, we will next year, again, have to limit our crop to meet present accommodation both in space and preserving qualities.

Moreover, I would bring to your notice the question of repainting which is so necessary to the preservation of our out buildings and school roof.

Since their erection none of these buildings have received a second coating of paint and after battling diversified weather conditions for so many years their appearances show the signs of many repurposes. They by no means bespeak the harmony one expects to find prevailing in a government institution, and after the school's endeavors of the past year in placing the buildings in sympathy it is only proper that we should expect to have the Department stand behind us and improve them with a newer and fresher hue.

It is estimated that 100 gallons of paint will be required and we trust that the Department will accede to our requests.

Finely, the question of a store-room of sufficient capacity to accommodate our year's supply of flour is most vital. It is necessary that we procure our wants in carlots which saves us much on transportation and always assures having a sufficient quantity on hand.

Our present storage space is hardly large enough to allow for storing half a carlot and has three large heating pipes running through it. The flour has necessarily to be piled high resulting in heavy losses due to insects getting into the flour and cereals.

Furthermore, our entire supply has had to be investigated and was stored in the garage and other places where rook could be found, thus leaving it open to the weather and rodents to increase our already heavy loss.

This same condition has existed each year and the school has borne the loss annually. However, that no other means of help seems forthcoming we would ask that the Department kindly give us a helping hand and help us in our move for "SUCCESS."

Trusting that our requests may meet with favor,

Obediently yours,

L. H. Rivet, O. M. I.
Principal.
