LEJAC INDIAN SCHOOL GOOD

Fine Progress Made in Developing Institution; Agriculture is Stressed

By HARRY BOWMAN

PRINCE GEORGE—The Indian residential school at Lejac is rapidly becoming one of the leading agricultural institutions in the province. Located on the south shore of beautiful Fraser Lake and surrounded by the wilderness, it provides ideal scenic surroundings for academic and practical training.

The school site was located by happy accident in 1912 when Rev. Father Coeckel, a convert with Indian blood, was camping near the lake visiting Indian settlements. A high wind caused the lake to break through and the lance was breached. It was then Father Coeckel discovered the possibilities of establishing a school in these ideal agricultural and scenic surroundings. Following his discovery and recommendation, there was a flurry of agitation and exchange of letters until the buildings were constructed and the school opened in 1922.

There are approximately 225 acres of land, of which 155 are now under cultivation. Five acres are seeded to alfalfa. This crop has produced heavily even of fields sowed down for eight years. Thirty acres were in wheat this season, and the balance of cultivated land in oats and the remainder in feed, potato garden and hay land. Four hundred and eighty acres of additional land have been rented for pasture and crops of grain.

The school has an average attendance of 160 pupils. These come from Shuswap, Thompson, Chilcotin, Tzalda and Tremblay Lake districts, and from reserves that are within the circle of which the above points are most distant.

BALANCED PROGRAMME

Every phase of agricultural activity is emphasized in order that the children on entering the school may be equipped to produce all necessary foods for table use. The girls are instructed in home cooking and preserving, sewing and butter making. The boys take their turn in the regular farm work in addition to their regular academic subjects and manual training.

The dairy herd comprises 36 head of Holstein cattle. Many are registered and are enrolled in the Canadian Dairy Association. Five excellent registered Holstein cows and heifers were recently purchased from the Tranquille Sanatorium at Prince George. The herd sire "Agassiz Re-echo Rajah," by "Agassiz Tussie Rajah," was added to the herd last season. This bull's dam "Agassiz Old Piette Re-echo" has a record of 17,241 pounds of milk and 662 pounds of butter from her ten-day milking. It is expected that a beef herd will be started shortly to furnish the meat requirements of the school.

Special attention is being paid to the raising of poultry. Five hundred and fifty white Leghorn pullets and 100 Barred Rocks from specially selected stock were hatched early this year. Two modern poultry houses fitted with running water, electric lights and Dutch ovens were completed in case the winter proves severe.

Thirty-three head of commercial sheep have been introduced this season. This flock is to be enlarged as accommodation is prepared.

Fifteen hives of bees were set out this spring. They are doing well, and Rev. Father Byrne Grant, the principal, hopes to increase the number up to 50 or more hives.

Four brood sows of Yorkshire breeding are maintained to take care of the pork requirements of the institution.

The horsepower consists of seven Clydesdale mares, two of them registered. A few good colts have been raised.

A complete line of farm machinery is owned and includes a threshing outfit and modern haying equipment.

Every attempt is being made to make the school self-supporting as possible, and at the same time to give the students a practical knowledge of the best agricultural practices.

The farm buildings are modern in every respect, but not elaborate. Running water and electric lights are provided by their own power and lighting plants. In fact every detail tending toward comfort for stock and caretaker has been considered in the construction of the buildings and arranging the farm, fields and programme.

This institution stands as a monument to the foresight of Father Coeckel and the Indian Department at Ottawa. The possibilities of a practical school have been realized. Father Coeckel have taken form under the guiding hands of the succeeding principals, with the co-operation of A. J. F. Rea.
Lejac, B.C.

June 30th 1937.

Report for quarter ending June 30th 1937.

Mr. R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent,
Vanderhoof, B.C.

Dear Sir,

I beg to submit the following report for the quarter ending June 30th 1937.

Health. We have been very fortunate this year and apart from an epidemic of colds and sore throats during the last week of the term, we have had no sickness in the school.

Mr. Hocking the Dentist from Prince George, passed five days and the school and examined all the children.

Dr. Pitts, the medical officer for the School, left us last week and is succeeded by Dr. Poole, who seems very interested in his work. We were sorry to see Dr. Pitts leave as he has been giving us very good service and not only came regularly for his weekly visit but was always glad to come if we called him.

Attendance. The regulations of the Dept. concerning permission to go home during the year has been rigorously enforced and very few of the children were allowed to go home during the year.

Conduct. With two or three exceptions among the older boys, the conduct of the children has been excellent.

Morale. In my last report I mentioned that I had been pleasantly surprised on coming to the School in January, to find the children apparently quite content and happy and I am glad to be able to report that up to the last day, this spirit has been maintained.

Class-room

Class-work. The Sisters in charge of the class-rooms seem very satisfied with the work done and the progress made by the children. The rainy weather, which made outside work difficult, helped to keep them content at their desks till the last day.

Outside work. Not very much outside of the routine work has been done during this quarter. This is partly due to the weather and partly to the decision to keep the boys in the class-room during the rush of the spring work, when it was difficult to provide the necessary supervision.

Manual training. Apart from the usual farm work, the older boys have had an opportunity of learning more about practical carpentry and cement work. We have built a new hen-house near the girls' play ground and the work is a credit to the carpenter and the boys who helped him. Several of the boys have shown marked aptitude in this kind of work and one has been hired to work with the carpenter during the holidays.

On the girls side, the usual work of mending and making clothes has kept them busy and not one of them will leave the school without having acquired a certain proficiency in the essentials of good house-keeping.
As I write today, conditions look very promising for our crops. A late spring, then three weeks of very dry weather and then ten days of rain had made the outlook rather sombre but if we have a continuance of the present weather we shall have an abundant harvest of hay, green feed and potatoes.

We have recently joined the cow-testing association and we hope that this will be a big help in building up a good herd of pure-bred Holsteins. In our last report we referred to the purchase of eight head of holsteins. Owing to unforeseen delays, these animals have not yet arrived but we hope to have them by the middle of July.

A considerable extension of our poultry work is being done and in the fall we hope to have 600 laying hens. One of the poultry houses will be looked after by the girls and some of the boys will help with the rest.

We hope to be able to finish clearing and to put into winter wheat, ten acres of land south of the highway. This will leave us about twenty acres of land to be cleared.

For some years past the attention of the Dept. has been called to the need of better provision for the keeping of potatoes and roots. This need is greater than ever this year as the cellar we have been using has started to give in and the same order under the barn is flooded. We have therefore taken advantage of the presence in the neighborhood of the Government bull-dozer, to have the excavations made for a large cellar near the school building. This work has begun. The big expense will be incurred in building the cement walls and putting the roof on and I hope that the Dept. will see fit to help us to meet this expense. We have planted over ten acres of potatoes this year and if we have a good crop, we would not have sufficient place in the old cellars for the potatoes alone without counting the cabbages, carrots and field roots.

We have a plumber working on the repairs to the septic tank and before long we should know just what will be needed to prevent the trouble we have been having on account of the laundry water flowing into the septic tank.

The unusually high level of the lake will prevent work on the intake pipes for sometime. The water is so high that the pump house is flooded and we have to use an auxiliary engine brought down from the school.

I think this covers all the important points that should be treated in this report.

Yours sincerely,

Rev. W. Byrne-Grant, O.M.I.
Principal.

March 31st, 1937

Mr. R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent,
Vanderhoof, B.C.

Dear Sir,

Herewith I beg to submit the report of the Lejac Indian Residential School for the year ending March 31st, 1937.

Staff. Since the last quarterly report there have been a few changes in the personnel of the administration. A new Principal, Rev. Father W. Byrne-Grant, O.M.I., and a vice-principal, Rev. Father J. Murphy, O.M.I., have been appointed. Mr. P. Corcoran, who has had long experience as supervisor of the boys, has been re-appointed for this work and I am glad to say that under the supervision of Rev. Father Murphy and Mr. Corcoran the discipline in the school is very good indeed.

Health. We have much to be thankful for on this point. In spite of the various epidemics that have swept other parts of the country and other schools, we have been fortunate enough to escape and during the last three months the health of the children has been excellent. We have, of course, the unpleasant duty of recording in this report the death of the four children on the 1st January. As I took over the duties of Principal after this accident occurred and as the Department has received from other sources a full report of the accident, I shall content myself with saying that we shall do all in our power to prevent the conditions which, according to some, made such an accident possible.

School morale. In spite of the accident I think I can truly say that the children are as happy and as well disposed as any group of children living in a residential school. During the last quarter there has been no attempt on the part of any of the children to run away. A skating rink constructed near the school itself and ideal weather for skiing and tobogganing has helped to keep them all in good humor. I may say that I have been agreeably surprised on this point and have found conditions far different to what I had expected.

Class-rooms. The report of the school inspector, who visited the school in January is the best testimony we could have of the good work being done by the Sisters. Mr. Barry expressed himself as very satisfied with the standing of the children and with the work done in the class-rooms.

Manual training. A few changes in this department have taken place during the last quarter. We have gone back to the system of having the boys do the milking both morning and night. They seem very interested in this work and in everything connected with the dairy cows and horses. I believe that the school is doing a very good work along these lines and in preparing the boys for the not distant time when the boys will have to take up farming more than they have done in the past. Another change has transferred to the girls the work of making butter. This was done in the past by women engaged for this purpose. We have found that under the supervision of the Sisters, the girls are making the butter just as well and more economically than under the other system. During the past three months, the problems arising from our severe winters have kept the boys busy. From now on they will be occupied with all the details of farm work.
We were very fortunate in having an abundant crop of hay last year and we are finishing the winter with a good supply on hand. The late fall with six weeks of extra grazing helped to reduce consumption.

We have been less fortunate with our live-stock. Sickness and injury have deprived us of two valuable horses and a pure-bred Holstein bull. To replace the former we have recently purchased two Clydesdale mares and to improve the dairy herd, we have bought from "Ranquille Farm and from the Indian Residential School at Mission, eight pure-bred heifers and one bull. The horses and dairy cows will cost us about $800.00. We now have a good dairy herd and I shall be greatly disappointed if we do not have some cows with very high milk records. The boys working in the barn are deeply interested in the daily record of the cows they milk.

We are planning to make some experiments with commercial fertilizers this year. We are going to have the advantage of expert advice from the Superintendent of the experimental farm at Agassiz. If these plans work out, we shall be able to set aside more land for pasture. This is our most serious problem.... our lack of pasture. The problem will not be solved permanently until we obtain more land.

We are planning to follow the advice of the Dominion Experimental farm and are making a start this year to produce our own certified seed potatoes. We are hoping to have increased production on a smaller acreage and every step in our experiments will be explained to the older boys.

In closing I would like to express my appreciation for the cooperation and kindness of the Indian Agent, Mr. R. H. Moore, who has shown a great interest in all the problems of the school. We would also like to thank Major MacKay, the Indian Commissioner, whose visit to the school this spring was very much appreciated.

Respectfully submitted,

W. Byrne-Grant, O.M.I.
Principal.
Dear Sir,

On February 18th, I received the following telegraphic communication, "Understand there is local feeling over tragedy whereby four Indian boys perished at Le Jac School New Years Day. Please investigate fully as soon as possible", signed Harold W. McGill.

Pursuant to these instructions I left Victoria on February 22nd, and, after dealing with certain departmental matters in Vancouver, proceeded by way of the P.G.E. Railway, to Quesnel and thence by motor car to Prince George, Vanderhoof and Le Jac. According to pre-arrangement Indian Agent Moore met me at Prince George and on Sunday, February 26th., we journeyed together to Vanderhoof where the agency headquarters are located.

As this was my first trip to the Stuart Lake Agency I spent the following day with Mr. Moore discussing agency matters in general and also called on Provincial Constable Jennings, Provincial Game Warden Brown and Road Foreman Parks, of whom I asked certain questions in connection with the main purpose of my visit to the district. About noon on March 2nd, accompanied by Mr. Moore and Mr. Lacey, Agency Clerk, I arrived at Le Jac Indian Residential School, having been somewhat delayed enroute from Vanderhoof owing to the heavy snows which had drifted to considerable depths along parts of the road. The Principal, Rev. Father Bryne-Grant, O.M.I., met us at the entrance to the school and extended a kindly welcome. After informing the Reverend Principal of the purpose of my visit, the first intim-

Dr. H.W. McGill,
Director, Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.
ation he had received to my knowledge, he proceeded to make arrangements for setting aside the necessary accommodation for our requirements.

The Le Jac Indian Residential School is an imposing brick structure of pleasing design standing on a gentle northerly slope and a few hundred feet southerly from the mid-south shore line of Fraser Lake, a clear view of a large part of which can be obtained from the school premises. The bricks used in the construction of the school were made on the ground from the soil of the Reserve property. The right-of-way of the Canadian National Railways passes through the school grounds approximately midway between the school itself and the aforementioned shore line, while the main highway, easterly to Vanderhoof and westerly to the community of Fraser Lake, passes a few hundred yards higher up the slope to the south of the school. Much of the acreage of the school property is under cultivation, the returns from which I understand are quite satisfactory; the water supply is abundant and of good quality.

The location of this school is a suitable one from the point of view of centrality, transportation facilities and soil and water advantages, and indicates much careful thought and study on the part of those responsible for the choice of the premises for this institution.

The purport of your telegram could be taken to indicate that the investigation should be confined to ascertaining the extent of the local feeling existing as a result of the tragedy whereby four pupils of the Le Jac School perished, but after careful thought, I decided to place a broader interpretation on
your instructions and proceed along lines which would, if possible, amplify the evidence already before the Department and more definitely determine the underlying causes which led up to the loss of the four children.

Before opening the investigation I had a short talk with the Rev. Principal when I informed him that I wished to call separately, certain members of his staff for examination and, principally those who were members of the staff prior to his arrival and assumption of the principalship. After consulting with the Sister Superior, Father Grant consented to this procedure but requested, on behalf of the Sister Superior, that she be permitted to be present when the Sisters were being questioned, to this I agreed.

I was surprised and disappointed on opening the inquiry to find that Bishop Coudert together with Father McGrath, Acting Principal at the time of the tragedy, and Disciplinarian Donze were not available for examination. Bishop Coudert was on a visit to the reserves in the western part of the agency, Father McGrath had gone to Baker City, Washington, immediately after the arrival of Father Bryne-Grant at Le Jac on January 7th, and Disciplinarian Donze was in the Hazelton area on missionary work to which he had been transferred early in January. It will be recalled that Father McGrath and Disciplinarian Donze gave evidence before the Coroner's jury at Fraser Lake on January 4th, but Bishop Coudert was in the western part of his diocese at this time and was not available to give evidence. The witnesses examined by me were, Provincial Constable Jennings of Vanderhoof, Indian Harry Paul, Indian Sylvester Patrick, Indian Charley
Charley, Indian Louie George, Indian (Mrs) Sylvester Patrick, Rev. Mr. Dobson, United Church Minister, Fort Fraser; Sister Superior Josephine, Sister Noella, Sister Cecile, Father Marsigny, Patrick Joseph Corcoran, Brother Anderson, Dr. C. Pitts, Fraser Lake, Paul Alex (Indian Boy), and Rev. Father Byrne-Grant O.M.I.

The evidence discloses that five boys, Allen Patrick aged 9, Andrew H. Paul aged 8, Justa Maurice aged 8, John Michel Jack aged 7 and Paul Alex aged 10 left the school without permission on the afternoon of January 1st., between 4.30 and 5 o'clock. Earlier in the day Bishop Coudert, who was in charge during the absence of Acting Principal McGrath had refused permission to these boys to visit Nautley Indian Village because of their age and the sub zero weather conditions. Father Donze before the Coroner's jury inquiring into the tragedy, stated he saw the boys at 4 P.M. on January 1st., and it is therefore safe to assume the children waited for their afternoon lunch, which on this particular day was not served until 4.30 P.M., before they left the school.

The children were not in their places for the evening meal at 6 o'clock and their absence was noticed and reported to the Sister Superior immediately by Sister Noella who was in charge of the diningroom at the time. The Sister Superior communicated this information to Father Marsigny who, is reported to have stated in reply, "I know they are missing, they asked and obtained permission from the Bishop to go"; Father Marsigny disclosed in his evidence that the latter part of this statement was based on supposition and he also gave the time when he
was first informed of the children's absence as 6 P.M. It is important here to note that although Father McGrath, the Acting Principal had returned to the school about 5 P.M. and was known to be in the school, and was therefore actually in charge, no attempt was made to inform him of the children's absence and, in this, is quite definitely indicated that lack of cooperation in the administration of the school which can be accepted as one of the contributing causes of the tragedy.

On leaving the school the five children went straight down to the railway tracks which they followed easterly for about one mile to a point where the shore line of Fraser Lake breaks in close to the railway right-of-way, here four of the children decided to strike across the lake in the direction of the Village, the fifth, Paul Alex eldest of the group, not wishing to go on the lake nor continue the journey along the tracks alone, decided to return to the school where he arrived before the close of the evening meal. The course on the lake followed by the four boys was fairly direct up until they encountered open water at the outlet of Fraser Lake, a distance of about 5 miles, this open water the children attempted to ford but finding the depth too great were compelled to crawl back on the solid ice. To turn back when so close to the north shore of the lake within sight of the Village and safety, must have been tremendously disappointing and sorely discouraging to already greatly fatigued children and the added discomfort of wet and freezing clothing aggravated a situation which had become desperate. Resuming the journey from the open water in a south easterly direction, the children with great difficulty
reached a point on the lake approximately one quarter of a mile from Beaumonts Beach. The snow at this point was found to have been trampled over a small area and in places brushed aside by the children indicating they were nearing the point of exhaustion and unable to go on, wanted to rest; it was here they collapsed and died and their frozen bodies were found by Indian Charley Charley at 5.30 P.M. on January 2nd. The total distance covered by the children would be approximately eight miles and the time taken to reach the spot where their bodies were found is estimated at seven hours; on this basis it is concluded the children perished at midnight on January 1st or there-after, or between seven and eight hours after they left the school.

The delay in informing Acting Principal McGrath of the absence without permission of the children was a very serious and costly omission, quite inexcusable and cannot be explained away by weak assumptions nor a shifting of responsibility; this should not have occurred, nor would have occurred, where administrative authority and responsibility were known, definitely fixed, appreciated and recognized. It is not too much to say that Father McGrath as Acting Principal had been dissatisfied for sometime prior to the tragedy, he gave evidence of this at the coroner's inquest, he did not know the extent of his authority as Acting Principal, nor the scope of his responsibilities as such, nor had he been informed what these were. Father McGrath's position was uncertain and the situation was complicated when he became Acting Principal by the addition to
the staff, much against his wishes, of two French Disciplinarians neither of whom had any knowledge of the English language; scholarly and well meaning young men, no doubt, but quite unsuited for the responsible positions in which they were placed. As Father McGrath could not speak French, the Disciplinarians became inclined to consult Bishop Coudert on matters within the jurisdiction of the Acting Principal, this no doubt had a tendency to weaken Father McGrath's administrative control of the staff and school with results which could not have been satisfactory to him. The evidence definitely indicates a lack of that cooperation between the Acting Principal and the subordinate staff most essential to the successful administrative management of an Institution such as an Indian Residential School and, it is hardly necessary to look beyond this, for the foundational cause that led up to the loss of the four children.

I consider the main reasons given for not organizing a search party between 6 P.M. and 9.15 P.M. on the night of January 1st., as weak and unsupported by reliable evidence. It was definitely established that only a few Indians visited the school on New Year's Day, most, if not all of whom, started for their homes prior to 4.30 P.M., the time when the five boys are supposed to have left the school. I am of the opinion from the evidence and information before me, had energetic action been taken to organize a search party when the absence of the children was first noticed and reported, the children would not have perished.

Father McGrath was well liked by the school children and highly regarded by their parents. There was no evidence to
show that punishment of any kind had anything whatever to do with the boys leaving the school without permission. It was simply a natural desire for freedom and to be with their parents during the holidays. Nor did I find any justification for the statements and rumors regarding unwholesome food being supplied to the children. I questioned both parents and pupils closely on this point and, with the exception of Mrs. Sylvester Patrick mother of one of the dead children, whose evidence should be largely discounted because of her mental and physical condition, all spoke well of the quality and quantity of the food supply. In view of these facts it is clear that any attempt to picture Father McGrath as heartless, severe and generally disliked by the children or their parents cannot be sustained by the evidence.

I visited a number of Indian homes and discussed the tragedy with nearly all the adult Indians I met and although I found indications of unrest and resentment this was mostly confined to the relatives and friends of the dead children. There was no demand among the Indians or the residents of the white communities visited for a judicial inquiry, nor do I think such an inquiry at this time would be in the best interests of the Indians.

My investigations lead me to the conclusion that the Department should take steps to strengthen its administrative control of our Indian Residential Schools through the full use of the privilege which it reserves of approving the more important appointments to the staffs of these schools.
A transcript in duplicate of the evidence taken is forwarded herewith.

Yours faithfully,

Indian Commissioner of B.C.

"I am pleased to hear that the report of the school Inspector, Capt. Berry, was very favorable and that the Department is pleased with the condition of the school.

Probably the same will that bring this letter to you will bring also a letter to the Department from the Indian Agent at Vanderhoof submitting for the approval of the Department regulations concerning the visits of Indians to the school. After my experience during the last ten months I feel sure that these regulations are needed in order to prevent any recurrence of the conditions which made last year's tragedy possible. Should these regulations come to you for action I would be glad if you would give them very favorable consideration.

The formal approval of the Department is really necessary for the success of these regulations. The Indians are under the impression that the school belongs to them and that the principal has no right to interfere with their coming and going and the very fact that these regulations would seem to come from the principal alone would convince them that they are based on the personal opinion and wishes of the principal himself rather than on any definite policy laid down by the Department.

The Commissioner and the Inspector of Schools have impressed upon me again and again that the Department holds responsible for anything that may occur at the school. I am sure that this is quite reasonable but I feel also that the Department should be willing to assume responsibility for regulations considered absolutely necessary for the safeguarding of the welfare of the children.

I have sometimes felt that there is a reluctance on the part of some of the officials of the Department to assume their share of responsibility in matters of this kind for fear that it might impair their popularity or friendly relations with the Indians with whom they are in constant contact. There is perhaps a tendency to "pass the buck" and to leave to the principal the odium of disagreeable decisions."

"That is why in this particular case I am anxious to have the Department give something more than their moral support to these regulations.

The Indians are fond of threatening to write to the Department when they think that they are treated too sternly and it would be just as well to forestall letters of this kind by giving official approval to the regulations.

I do not suppose for one moment that another tragedy will occur but I certainly would like to show both to the Indians and to the general public (who I am told have their eye on Lejac School) that there is complete co-operation between the Department and the local officials.

If you have anything to do with the budgets of the different Indian schools you will no doubt smile at our famous "marry a mule" root cellar and pig pen. They appear again this year and I am wondering if there is any possibility or rather if there is anything we could do to impress upon the Department the real need that we have for these two buildings.

SCHOOLS

I inspected the Residential school at LeJac, Fraser Lake.

In view of the regrettable deaths of some of the boys last winter here, I had a long, confidential talk with the Principal, chiefly upon the matter of divided authority, on account of the residence there of a Bishop, for so long a time. Central B.C. Indian School
Does Valuable Work at Lejac

The Indian Residential School at Lejac is rapidly becoming one of the leading agricultural institutions in the province.

Located on the south shore of beautiful Fraser Lake and nestled in the foothills it has ideal scenic surroundings for academic and practical training.

The school was founded by happy accident in 1912 when Reverend Father Cocola, in company with Indian guides, were canoeing on the lake visiting Indian settlements.

A high wind caused the lake to become rough and the canoe took water. The Indians jumped ship to dump the canoe and it was then Father Cocola discovered the possibilities of the land and its potentialities in these ideal agricultural and scenic surroundings.

Following his discovery and recommendation there was a long period of negotiation and exchange of letters, until the beautiful buildings were constructed and the school opened in 1926.

Rev. Father J. Allaire was principal during the following years. Rev. Father Cocola, who looked after the institution for ten years. Rev. Father Riley was principal from 1933 to 1936 and the present incumbent, Rev. Father Byrne Grant. Each of the principals left his mark in beautifying and improving the school farm.

GROW ALFALFA

There are approximately 225 acres of land of which 150 are under cultivation. Fifty-five acres are seeded down for alfalfa and produced heavily even on fields seeded down for eight years. Thirty acres are planted to this crop and the balance of cultivated land in oats and peas for green feed, potatoes, garden and hay land.

Hundreds and eighty acres of additional land have been rented for pasture and cereal grains.

The school has an average attendance of 160 pupils. These come from Shuswap, Hazelton, Kamloops, Tahltan and Thompson Lake districts and from reserves within the vicinity of which the above points are mentioned.

The school's dairy herd comprises cows, heifers and Holstein cattle. Many are registered and are enrolled in the local cow-testing association. Twenty-five Holstein cows and heifers were recently purchased from the Trappelle Sanatorium Farm. The herd sire, Agassiz Re-Echo Rajah, by Agassiz Re-Echo Rajah, was added to the herd this season. A beef herd has been started recently to furnish the meat requirements of the school.

Special attention is being paid to the raising of poultry. Five hundred and fifty White Leghorn pullets and five hundred cockerels from specially-selected stock were purchased early this year. Two modern poultry houses equipped fitted with running water, electric lights, and Dutch ovens were constructed in case the winter proves severe.
British Columbia Indian School Has Fine Location

The Indian Residential School at Lejac is rapidly becoming one of the best agricultural institutions in British Columbia. Located on the south shore of beautiful Fraser Lake and nestled in the foothills of the Interior it provides ideal scenic surroundings for academic and practical training.

The school site was located by happy accident in 1912 when Father Cocola in company with Indian guides were exploring the Lake visiting Indian settlements. A high point on the land became rough and the party were forced ashore. It was there that the idea came to Father Cocola of establishing a school in these ideal agricultural and scenic surroundings. After making his discovery and recommendation there were many years of agitation and exchange of letters until the buildings and grounds were constructed and the school opened in 1925. Reverend Father J. Allard was principal for the first year followed by Reverend Father Cocola who looked after the Institution for ten years. Rev. Father Rivet was principal from 1936 to 1940 and the present incumbent is Rev. Father Wm. Byrne Grant.

There are approximately 225 acres of land of which 155 are now under cultivation. Fifty-five acres are seeded to alfalfa. This crop has been very even and fields seeded down for eight years. Thirty acres are in wheat this season and the balance of cultivated land is used for peas for green feed, potatoes, garden and some pasture. The land has been rented for pasture and cereal crops.

The school has an average attendance of 160 pupils. These come from Shelley, Hazelton, Clinton, Tahltan, Trappleye Lake districts and from reserves where within the mile of which the above points are more distant.

Every phase of agricultural activity is emphasized in order that the children on leaving school will be equipped to provide all necessary foods for table use. The girls are instructed in house cooking and preserving, sewing and baking. The boys take their turns at the regular work connected with the regular academic subjects and manual training.

The dairy herd comprises twenty-six head of registered cattle. Many are registered and are entered in the British Cow Testing Association. Five excellent registered Holstein cows and heifers were recently purchased from the Tranquille Station Farm. The herd sire Agassiz Re-Echo Rajah by Agassiz Old Pootie Rajah was added to the herd this season. This bull's dam, Agassiz Old Pootie Re-Echo has a record of producing pounds of milk and 662 pounds of butter fat on one hundred milking. A beef herd has been started this fall to further the educational programme of the school. A couple of carloads of Hereford beefers from the drought areas of the Prairies have been on feet at Lejac.

Special attention is being paid to the raising of poultry. Five hundred and fifty White Leghorns, one hundred and sixty Barred Rocks from specially selected stock were purchased early last fall. Two modern chicken houses were erected fitted with running water, electric lights and Dutch ovens were constructed in anticipation of winter proves severe.

Thirty-three head of commercial sheep have been introduced this season. This flock is to be enlarged as accommodation is available. Four brood sows of Yorkshire breeding are maintaining and taking care of the pork requirements of the institution.

A complete line of farm machinery is on hand and includes a threshing outfit, and modern hay equipment. Every attempt is being made to make the school as self-sustaining as possible and at the same time to give the students a practical knowledge of the best agricultural practices.
British Columbia Indian School Has Fine Location

The INDIAN Residential School at Shilo, Manitoba, is a fine example of the type of institution being established throughout British Columbia. Located on the banks of the Red River, the school is situated in an area providing ideal conditions for settlement. A high windmill, a water tank, and a large barn were among the first structures erected on the site.

The school was opened in 1935 by Father J. Allan, who was principal for ten years. Rev. Father J. Allan was parish priest of St. Patrick's Church, Winnipeg, from 1926 to 1936, and was appointed chaplain to the school in 1936.

The school has an average attendance of 160 pupils. These come from Shilo, Lakehead, and other towns within the circle of which these three points are situated.

The school has a fine location, with excellent facilities for agricultural activity. The emphasis placed on this activity is evident in the fact that all necessary food for the pupils is prepared on the school grounds. The boys spend their time at the regular farm work in addition to their academic studies.

The dairy herd comprises twenty-six cows and modern milking equipment. Every effort is made to give the students practical experience in farming.

A complete line of farm machinery is available for use by the students. In the spring, they plant vegetables and flowers, and in the fall, they harvest them.

The school provides a good education for its pupils, and the future looks promising for the students who attend.
ATTENDANCE

The attendance at the school for the first quarter is higher than usual for this time of the year. There are still about 25 children who should be here, but if they were all to come, we would not have room for them.

BEGINNERS

The number of new-comers is very satisfactory and is greater than the number who are being discharged after having reached the age-limit.

MORALE

While there are naturally some of the younger children who are home-sick and are having the usual difficulty in adjusting themselves to their new life, the children seem to have settled down very quickly to the routine of school life and we have not yet had any trouble about run-aways.

RUN-AWAYS

During the past two years we have had no trouble on this score. On one occasion two small boys managed to get about a mile from the school before being picked up, but there have been no other cases since then. Apparently, run-aways occur in cycles and of course we cannot be sure when they may start again.

CONDUCT and DISCIPLINE

The conduct and discipline of the children is very satisfactory. Those in charge of the children during recreation have good control and we anticipate very little trouble in this respect. Occasional use of the strap has to be made but in doing this care is taken to use only the methods approved by the Provincial regulations.

MANUAL TRAINING

In accordance with the wishes of the Dept., we are doing all we can to develop this branch of our work.

Girls

As far as the girls are concerned there is not very much more that can be done. They already are taught all the branches of domestic science and the work we are going to concentrate on the handling of wool; right from the sheep's back to the various finished articles: sweaters, blankets, mattresses, socks, gloves, etc.

Boys

We have been giving serious thoughts to the best of means of developing rapidly the program of manual training for the boys. The opportunities available at the school are sufficient in one sense. The farm itself provides the means of practical lessons in dairying and in the care of beef cattle, sheep, hogs, poultry and rabbits, while members of the staff have the necessary knowledge and equipment to give elementary training in carpentry, shoe-making and black-smithing.

Our difficulty is to find the necessary time for the routine "chores", the class-room work and the various branches of manual training we wish to develop. I hope to send to the Dept. a special memorandum on this subject in the very near future.
HEALTH

The health of the children is much better than at this time last year. The medical officer, Dr Irish, has completed a thorough examination of all the children. We are expecting a visit of Dr Wahl in the very near future to help us in our work of checking thraoma. Dr McQuarri was here about two weeks ago and we discussed the possibility of establishing a Preventorium here. We hope to have the school thoroughly examined by the Provincial T.B. traveling clinic, and when we have a complete report, Mr R.H. Moore, the Indian Agent will study the whole question with me.

CROPS

One of the driest years in the history of the country reduced our crops considerably. In fact, we have harvested less than half a crop of hay and cereals. The potato crop, which at first looked like a complete failure, now promises to be better than a half crop, thanks to some late rains.

LIVE STOCK

We are gradually developing this branch of our farm work and thus we are combining the advantage of producing our own food and the means of increasing the opportunities of practical farm instruction for the boys.

At present, we have:

- 22 Holstein cows & heifers and one bull
- 75 head of beef cattle and one bull
- 10 sows and a boar
- 1000 laying hens and a few geese and turkeys
- 8 horses
- 40 head of sheep
- 12 angora and heavy breed rabbits

IMPROVEMENTS

The new cellar (48 by 48) attached to the school building has been completed outside and the floor covered with 6 inches of gravel.

About one mile of new fencing has been built. Owing to some misunderstanding, the building of the new piggery was delayed but work is being started immediately.

An eight foot fence, 300 feet long is being built on two sides of the boys play ground to protect them from the cold winds from the lake.

Dear Mr. Moore:

I beg to submit the quarterly report for the quarter ending March 31st, 1938.

ATTENDANCE

At the end of the quarter the attendance was 157 (91 girls and 66 boys). This is ten more than the attendance for the previous quarter. If it were not for the fact that four girls were sent home for reasons of health we would have had a full attendance.

HEALTH

The medical officer, Dr. Poole, tells me that in general he is well satisfied with the health of the children. There have been no epidemics of any kind and the whooping-cough and German measles have disappeared completely. Four girls were sent home on account of pulmonary T.B. With regard to T.B. in the school the Doctor tells me that the cases mentioned above would have been diagnosed earlier if X-ray facilities had existed. It would be impossible to give a definite opinion about the prevalence of T.B. among the children without X-ray examination. We had one case of a boy who had been refused admittance several times on the ground of T.B. but when he was sent to Burns Lake for examination the X-ray showed no evidence of T.B.

Trachoma

With regard to the prevalence of Trachoma among the children Dr. Poole tells me that he has had no previous experience with this disease. He has examined all the pupils and finds that besides the known cases from the list given by Dr. Pitts (the previous medical officer) he has found that practically all the children are suspicious. Most of them have only the slight violet discolouration, which is the first sign. These cases are being treated as trachoma. The Doctor does not think that these are new cases which has developed in the past six months. Apparently the children had not been examined for trachoma during the past two years though treatment had been given to the known cases. Dr. Poole is very anxious to have a visit from Dr. Wahl as soon as possible so that he will have some definite guidance from a specialist.

MORALE

The spirit among the children is excellent. The facilities for winter sports provided for them at the beginning of the season have kept them busy and they all seem quite happy and contented.

DISCIPLINE

The discipline of the children is excellent. No unruly characters have developed since the beginning of the year and we have every reason to be pleased with the conduct of the children.
There have been no attempts to run away and while every precaution is being taken there does not seem to be any tendency on the part of the children to leave the school. The skating rink and the other winter sports have helped a great deal to make the work of the supervisors easy.

**MANUAL TRAINING**

The bigger boys have been kept busy not only in helping with the farm work but also have worked with the carpenter so that they have been able to learn something about repairing buildings and have been able to do a great deal of rough carpentry. The winter has been comparatively mild and they have been able to work outside much more than in previous winters.

**DOMESTIC TRAINING**

The girls are continuing the usual programme of training in all branches of work for which they are especially adapted. There is no doubt that every girl leaving the school is well able to undertake all the household duties such as cooking, sewing, washing and ironing.

**HANDICRAFTS**

The Exhibition of Indian Handicrafts at Vancouver has given us an opportunity to see just what can be done at the school. We find that the children have not learnt very much from their parents along these lines and if handicrafts are to be developed we shall have to count more on the training given at the school than on anything the children may learn from their parents. As I said in my last report these things cannot be done at once and we are therefore planning a programme which will take some time to develop.

**FARM OPERATIONS**

While the winter has been comparatively mild it has been just as long as usual and during the past quarter the outside work has consisted entirely of looking after the stock. The boys have their regular duties and those who enjoy this kind of work have an opportunity of learning all about the proper care of horses, dairy cows, beef cattle, pigs and poultry. Most of them seem to like this kind of work and would much rather be working among the animals than attending class. They even willingly give up their recreation if their help is especially needed.

**POULTRY**

We are well satisfied with the poultry experiment and while production is not as high now after our long winter the total production for the winter months has been very good indeed. We feel that it will be worth while developing the poultry branch of our activities as we find that it is possible to provide plenty of fresh eggs at very little cost.
PIG PEN

We would like to express our appreciation to the Department for having decided to replace the pig pen which was burnt down three years ago. Operations will begin as soon as weather permits and before next fall we hope to have the building completed and ten Purebred Yorkshire sows installed in their new home.

ROOT CELLAR

In order to provide for an unusually heavy crop of potatoes we have dug a cellar which connects with the school itself. The new cellar is forty eight by forty eight and will not only provide all the space we need but will also, on account of its location, obviate the necessity of having the children go outside during sub zero weather to bring in the vegetables. There is much work to be done yet in the cellar itself and we would be glad if the Department would keep this in mind should funds be available for improvements during the coming fiscal year.

During the winter months we did not usually expect or receive visits from any of the officials of the Department. No doubt we shall be more fortunate when winter is over and the roads become passable.

Yours truly,

Rev. W. Byrne-Grant, O.M.I.

VISITING REGULATIONS FOR LEJAC SCHOOL

A. Indians will not be permitted to camp in the school under any conditions. Camping in the school grounds will not be allowed as there are available camp grounds on the Reserve less than half a mile from School Buildings.

B. Indians visiting children at the school must not expect to have meals supplied to them even though they may be prepared to pay for such meals.

C. Both parents and children must remain in the Indian Parlor while in the school building. Parents wishing to see the school rooms, dormitories, infirmary or play rooms should be accompanied by a member of the staff.

D. Only the parents or the guardians of the children are allowed to visit the children or to be on the school property. Outside of visiting hours no one is allowed on the property unless he has business with the principal.

E. The ordinary visiting day is Sunday. The visiting hours are from twelve thirty till two. A bell will be sounded at two P.M. when all children will at once report to the Supervisors. Parents will be expected to leave the building before two P.M. at the latest.

F. Parents coming from long distances and only able to visit the school once or twice a year will receive permission to see their children outside of the regular visiting hours.

G. Parents coming by train from Stony Creek, Shelly, Ft. St. James, Tache, etc., will be allowed to see their children between trains on Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday.

H. Special regulations will be made for visiting hours at Christmas and Easter.

I. Permission cannot be given for children to leave the school to visit their parents, except when such cases have been referred to the Indian Agent and his sanction obtained in writing.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit the report for the quarter ending Dec. 31st, 1937.

ATTENDANCE

At the end of the quarter the attendance was 147 (86 girls and 52 boys). This is fourteen below the school quota. The reduction in the number of children is due to several reasons. First, the postponement of the opening of the school for two weeks resulted in some of the parents leaving for their trap lines with their children. It is possible that some of these children may be brought to the school at the end of the Christmas holidays. Secondly, the epidemic of measles and whooping-cough in the camps, which caused the postponement of the opening, left some of the children too sick to attend school. Some of these may return now. Thirdly, the number of the children discharged at the end of the school year was greater than usual. The accident last year does not seem to have had any effect on recruiting.

HEALTH

The medical officer, Dr. Poole, tells me that he is well satisfied with the general health of the children. There were some cases of whooping-cough and German measles and all the children seemed to have bad colds when they arrived at the school but now the children all seem quite well. There is of course the occasional indisposition and occasionally we find one or two children in the infirmary but there is nothing serious.

MORALE

The spirit among the children is excellent. Every provision has been made to provide them with ample facilities for winter sports. The children are provided with a full sized skating rink, skis, and sleighs and everyone visiting the school remarks on the evident contentment of the children.

DISCIPLINE

The discipline of the children is excellent. The departure of three rather unruly boys at the end of the school year has helped a great deal and we have every reason to be pleased with the conduct of the children so far. Earlier in the year two little boys from Tache tried to run away from sheer homesickness but this is the only case. Of course every precaution is being taken. The location of the skating rink close to the school building instead of down on the lake has helped to maintain the necessary control and render far easier the work of the supervisors.
VISITS

It is generally agreed that one of the contributing causes to the accident last year was the disorder caused by the number of Indians visiting the school at one time and the fact that several families from out-lying points were camped in the Indian parlor. Steps have been taken to control the days and hours of visiting so that while ample facilities are granted to the parents to visit their children the inconvenience of having to greet a number come at the same time is being avoided. The Indians are no longer allowed to camp in the Indian parlor. This latter regulation is not without its drawbacks and I believe that some means should be provided to enable parents coming from distant camps to remain near the school for a few days. These people usually make their visits during the winter months when climatic conditions make camping outdoors rather difficult. This is especially true for those who come by train and do not bring with them the usual equipment for camping in woods. I believe that the final solution of this problem will be found in the construction of a suitable building along the lake shore for the use of the parents visiting their children. This problem dates back many years. In 1926 the Department received complaints from the Indians directed against Rev. Father Coccola because he refused to allow them to camp in the school. In answering these complaints, Rev. Father Coccola stated that he had suggested to the Indians that they collect the necessary materials for the construction of the building for their use, but nothing was done and it is unlikely that the Indians themselves will have enough energy or initiative to do anything themselves. I believe that for £200 it would be possible to build and equip a small house which would meet the needs of the Indians and remove finally all ground of complaint on this point. It would be better that the building be constructed by the school itself as it would enable us to have full control of the building and prevent any abuse of it. I would like to recommend to the Department that a grant be made for this purpose.

While discussing the question of visits it might not be amiss to draw attention to the inconveniences caused by the visits of some disorderly Indians. On two occasions at least the whole school was upset by the conduct of these Indians who were evidently under the influence of liquor. On another occasion several young Indians even went so far as to be insulting to the Sisters in charge of the girls. It is unfortunate that the impression seems to exist that any Indian has the right at any time to walk into the school building and that neither the principal nor those directly in charge of the children have any right to control their conduct. Regulations are being drawn up to meet the situation and I hope that in my next report I will be able to say that the abuses caused by visits of this kind have been completely checked.

MANUAL TRAINING

The first two months kept the boys busy harvesting the root crops and preparing for winter. Since then the usual winter program is being followed. There are fewer big boys this year so that we are not able yet to divide them up in such a way as to permit some of them to specialize in carpentry as we did last year. They are however getting practical experience in building work both around the school building and in connection with the farm.

One change has been made from last year's program partly due to the small number of big boys and partly to the sickness that was prevalent when they returned from the camps. We have not used the boys for milking the cows. I have sometimes wondered whether it would not be just as well to discontinue this practice altogether. The fact that most of the children have P. D. in their system leads me to think that in order to safeguard the purity of the milk it would be better to get on without them for this work. I believe also that in the camps the men do not bother about work of this kind which is left to the care of the women.

DOMESTIC TRAINING

The girls are continuing the usual program of training in all branches of work for which they are especially adapted. I think we can say without exaggeration that the girls leaving the school are really well trained in cooking, plain and fancy sewing, washing and ironing, and in general house work.

HANDICRAFTS

Steps are being taken to prepare the school to be in a position to take up special handicraft work. We shall make a beginning this year by making our first attempt at teaching the children to make Indian sweaters, scarves and stockings with home spun wool from our own flock of sheep. We are planning to gradually expand this work so that every child will leave the school able to earn money by means of one of these handicrafts.

FARM OPERATIONS

Winter came early this year and practically all our work now consists in looking after the stock and meeting the difficult conditions which go with our severe winters. Some of the boys spend at least an hour and a half each day in this work. We are wintering about one hundred head of stock including thirty six head of high grade Hereford heifers which we imported from the prairies as the foundation of our beef herd. I believe that this will afford useful training to many of the boys whose parents are engaged in raising beef for the market.
Poultry

The experiment begun last spring of increasing the poultry flock and of showing to the Indians what can be done with poultry even in the coldest weather has been quite successful even in the coldest sub-zero weather. We are getting as high as four hundred eggs a day from six hundred hens and we are thus in a position to supply the school with all the fresh eggs needed and at the same time sell enough to pay for operating costs. This experiment will be useful not only to the Indians themselves but also to the farmers of the neighbourhood.

Root Cellar and Pig Pen

We are still hoping to receive news that the Department is going to help to provide us with these two buildings which still are our most pressing needs.

We have had the pleasure since our last report of receiving visits of Major D. M. MacKay, the commissioner, and from Inspector G. H. Barry. Their visits were both helpful and encouraging and were greatly appreciated. I would like also to express my appreciation for the active co-operation of Mr. R. H. Moore, the Indian Agent. He has visited the school frequently and not only shows a great interest in all our doings but has been a great help in connection with various problems that have come up. I might also mention that during the past year we have received many visits from Federal and Provincial officials of the Department of Agriculture who have been greatly interested in our work and have helped in many ways.

Yours truly,

Rev. W. Byrne-Grant, O.M.I.

Dear Sir:

I regret to have to announce to you that the Rev. W. B. Grant, O.M.I., the Principal of the Lejac Residential School at Lejac, B.C., left the school two days ago.

Having a too keen sense of his responsibility attached to the conduct of the school he felt anxious to be relieved of the burden; hence he accepted a call to Buffalo, tendered his resignation and was obliged to leave on short notice.

I have the satisfaction, however, to propose as his successor at Lejac a man in every way qualified to fill the position in the person of the Rev. Alexander Robertson Simpson, O.M.I. He is a British subject, born in Scotland, a good disciplinarian, expert business man; and has acted as assistant at the school for several months and is familiar with all the details of the school. I feel sure that he will make an efficient principal; hence, I have no hesitation to recommend him to you for his official appointment from Ottawa.

Yours very truly,

E. M. Bunoz, O.M.I.,
Bishop of Prince Rupert.
Attendance.

There are actually 180 children in the school at present, and three others in the hospital. Once more I wish to draw the attention of the Department to the fact that we are only receiving the per capita grant for 160 children, which makes things increasingly difficult for us.

Morale.

The spirit of the children is very good, and we have not yet had a single runaway this year.

Manual Training.

This phase of the training of the children is following the customary lines, and with considerable success.

Health.

We have been greatly inconvenienced during the past three months by the fact we did not have a local doctor; and were obliged to call Dr. Stone from Vanderhoof when necessary. Dr. Stone has been very considerate and has always answered our call, but Vanderhoof is 40 miles away, and the telephone service is not very reliable. There have been two cases of pneumonia and one boy broke his arm, in addition to various other minor ailments.

On the whole the health of the student body is very good.

Crops.

Once again our potato crop was a failure, and we were obliged to purchase a carload of potatoes from Kamloops at very great expense.

Livestock.

All of the livestock are doing well, and the numbers are about the same as in the last report. The pigs are now established in the new piggery and appear to be quite contented. The chickens have done well, and a fair profit has been realised from the sale of eggs. Some additional has been earned by the sale of cream and pork, as well as hides.

Visual Education.

We are going in for this branch of education rather strongly, and find the children very responsive. A silent 16mm projector has been purchased, and we also have projectors for glass and film slides; all of which the children enjoy very much indeed.

Dear Sir:

Having exhausted all the other channels of approach without result or acknowledgement from the Department, I now appeal directly to you.

If the credit and the good name of this school is to be maintained, and the Indian children are to continue to receive all of the services to which they are entitled, (as you directed in your letter to me of January 5th., 1939) it is imperative that an increase of pupilage be granted.

GENERAL REPORT
for quarter ending September 30th., 1940.

ATTENDANCE.
Considerable difficulty has been experienced this year in bringing the children back to school. At the orders of the Department, we tried to have the parents bring their children at least part of the way into school; but they obstinately refused. Finally the services of the Mounted Police had to be requested. We are still about 20 children short of the desired number.

Moralet
Those of the children who have returned seem to be in good spirits. There have been no attempts to run away, as yet.

MANUAL TRAINING
This is proceeding along the customary lines, carpentry and farm instruction for the boys; and the usual household work for the girls, combined with instruction in spinning, carding, rug-making, dressmaking, etc.

HEALTH
Soon after the children returned we had a severe attack of the "flu." No one in the house escaped, and at one time we had over 70 children in bed at the same time. It seems to be almost over now, there are only two or three children left in bed.
One girl was sent to the hospital that day after she came, with incipient pneumonia.

CROPS
The yield was good this year. Harvesting is almost finished. It will not be necessary to purchase potatoes this year, as in the past two years. We also have enough feed on hand for our stock. The garden was good this year, and large quantities have been canned for the winter.

LIVESTOCK
The animals are all in good shape, and the numbers remain about the same. The lamb and pig crops have been disposed of at fair prices.

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.
Principal
ATTENDANCE.

The number of children in the school is still over 130. Due to the reduction in authorised pupilage it will be necessary to reduce the number of children for the next school year to about 150. Probably, no more children will be accepted from outside of the Stuart Lake Agency, except in the case of orphans or destitute children.

MORALE.

The morale of the children is very high. They are very well behaved, and give little trouble. There have been no runaways this year.

HEALTH.

On the whole, the health of the children has been good. We had a severe siege of the "flu," and at one time we had sixty children in bed at the same time. There have been three children sent to the hospital for various reasons.

ACTIVITIES.

The Sisters and many of the girls are actively engaged in working for the Red Cross. Many articles such as pyjamas, pillowslips, towels, sox, etc., have already been made by them. The children take a very keen interest in this work, and well realise what it is for.

IMPROVEMENTS.

The root cellar has finally been fixed. Instead of the ponderous and costly concrete structure that had been planned, we removed all of the dirt, and put on a wooden roof, covered with rubberoid roofing. Under the roof there is about two and a half feet of sawdust and shavings for insulation. This makes a light and effective roof, that will be much better than the old one, and just as efficient as a more costly one of concrete. The cost of this work was about $250.00, exclusive of the labour.

LIVESTOCK.

The farm animals are all doing well. We had a lamb crop of about 60, and the calves are still coming. The chickens are producing well, and keeping up a large and steady supply of eggs. Our milk herd has the best average production in this district.

CROPS.

All of the seed is now in the ground, and provided we get sufficient rain, there should be a very good crop.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of the 16th. inst. is at hand; and I wish to inform you that the complaint of which you speak is entirely, and probably maliciously, false.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of the 6th instant addressed to the Minister of Labour has been referred to this Department for attention.

Inquiries are being made regarding your claim that aliens are being employed on the staff of the Lejac Indian Residential School.

Subsection 2 of Section 10 of the Indian Act provides that no Protestant Indian child shall be assigned to a Roman Catholic school or school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices, and no Roman Catholic child shall be assigned to a Protestant school or a school conducted under Protestant auspices. For the past 50 years it has been the policy of successive Governments to provide schools for both Catholic and Protestant children. The Lejac School is intended for Catholic Indian children and it is quite natural that only Catholics should be employed. At the Protestant Indian residential schools it is the usual custom to employ only Protestants.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,-

Our attention has been called to the fact that the Indian Industrial School at Lejac, B. C., is employing enemy aliens. The heads of this school are very often not Canadian or British subjects and do not seem to realize that it is not the proper thing to employ enemy aliens when these jobs can be done just as well by veterans or other Canadians out of work.

Further this school will employ nobody who is not a member of the R. C. Church. We understand that this school gets regular grants from the federal Government and it seems to us that discrimination against other churches is, to say the least, out of place.

We would kindly ask you to look into these matters and take the necessary steps.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

I wish to report a regrettable incident which occurred at the Lejac Indian Residential School last Saturday afternoon. About 4 P.M., the local telephone operator received a rather incoherent message that Herman Hesse, carpenter and Manual Training Instructor had gone berserk and stabbed the Rev. A.H. Simpson, the Principal, several times. Doctor Stone, the local Provincial Police Constable and myself proceeded to the school without delay. On arrival it was found that Mr. Sadler, another workman employed at the School, was the victim; not Father Simpson.

From inquiries made it would appear that Father Simpson discharged Hesse about ten days ago and gave him one month's notice to vacate. Mr. Hesse proceeded to Prince Rupert to voice his objections to the Right Rev. E.M. Bumz, the Bishop in charge of this diocese. On his return to the School last Saturday the Principal cancelled his month's notice for reasons given in the attached statement and ordered Hesse to leave immediately. Apparently Hesse worked himself into a terrible frenzy and proceeded to manhandle the Principal, kicking him in the groin and around the face. Mr. Sadler, a witness, grappled with Hesse before he could inflict any wounds on the Principal and received six flesh wounds himself. Mr. Hesse later withdrew to his room, in the bunkhouse where we found him still in a very nervous state. He was taken into custody and placed in the Vanderhoof lock-up; no doubt a charge of inflicting grievous bodily harm will be preferred against him in due course. I understand Hesse is of Czech-German origin but is a naturalised British citizen. He has been employed at the school for the past six years. He struck me as being a very thorough workman but prone to become excited over fanciful grievances. He is also a powerfully built man of huge proportions and it is fortunate that he desisted when he did as he might and could have created havoc in the frame of mind he was in.

An affair of this kind is indeed to be regretted, although no blame can be attached to anyone at the school. The publicity which will necessarily follow may have a bad odour and will not tend to increase the popularity of the school with the Indians or the general public.

Doctor Stone advises that Mr. Sadler's wounds are not serious and that he should be fully recovered in four or five weeks' time.

Your obedient servant,

Robert Howe,
Indian Agent.

Herman Hesse was discharged by me from the employ of this school on February 1st. He declared that he would go to Prince Rupert and fix it with Bishop Bunoz. Then he told the other men that he was going to get even with me; and that he would accuse me of improper conduct with Mrs. Sadler, the wife of one of the hired men.

Hesse returned from Rupert at 1 p.m. today. I told him to get his things together and get out this afternoon. At 3 p.m., I went over to his room to warn him to leave once more. He refused to go, and I said that I would have the police to put him out. He then demanded to be paid until April 1st. I refused. Then he said that I had given him a month's notice, and that he was going to work it out. I told him that I did not know then what a "dirty swine" he was, but now that I had found out, he had to leave immediately.

Then Hesse attacked me, kicking me in the leg and in the groin. He kicked me out of the house, and I thought that he was going to strike me with his fist. Anton Sadler, a farm worker of the school, came running up and yelled at Hesse. Hesse then swore at Sadler and knocked him down and stabbed him repeatedly with a knife. I did not realise then that it was a knife until Sadler cried out that he had been stabbed. Then Father Pagnon and Tuck, our disciplinarian, came up; Hesse went into the house, and Sadler was taken upstairs.

I then phoned for the doctor and police.

(Signed)

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.

STATEMENT OF THOMAS H. M. TUCK, Disciplinarian at Lejac School.

Having returned to the yard with the boys, was talking to Father Pagnon. Heard a scuffle behind me, turned and saw Mr. Hesse, over Mr. Sadler, who was down on the ground. A minute or so later, Mr. Sadler got away and ran towards the school, when he passed me, I saw his blue overall coat and shirt were cut, apparently with a knife, and there appeared to be a gash of about 8 inches on his left shoulder. After that Sadler was taken into the house. This is all that I can say.

(Signed)

STATEMENT OF FATHER PAGNON.

I was coming down from the barn, where I had a talk with Mr. Sadler. I passed the bunkhouse, I met Father Simpson, who said he was going to see Mr. Hesse, and find out whether he was getting ready to leave. At first, I had the impulse to accompany him, but did not do so. Not far off, I stopped to talk with Mr. Tuck. A few moments later, I heard the argument between Father Simpson and Hesse. Just after I saw Fr. Simpson coming out of the house, I noticed that he was pale. Right after Hesse followed still arguing, and pursuing him, I saw him lifting his fist on Father Simpson. I did not see a knife. Mr. Sadler was just coming around the corner of the house. He threw himself between Hesse and Fr. Simpson. Hesse began to strike him, at first I did not realise that he had a knife in his hand. Then I saw that he had a knife. I went towards them. Hesse left Sadler, who got up and came to me crying "call the doctor."

Mrs. Sadler, who saw the whole thing, came to me also, and with her, I helped Sadler up to his room.

Signed.

ATTENDANCE.

Since the last report a few more children have been admitted, bringing our total attendance up to 165 pupils.

MORALE.

The children continue to be in the best of spirits, and seem to be very well satisfied with their lot here at the school. There has been no trouble as yet with runaways.

MANUAL TRAINING.

The boys completed the erection of the second storey of the chicken house, and did an excellent job. All of the cement work, and stair building, in fact, all of the actual work, was done by the boys, under the supervision of the Manual Training Instructor. They are now doing inside work, house maintenance and repair jobs, and the construction of small articles of furniture.

Health.

The X-ray clinic held here brought to light only five active cases of tuberculosis, and three others recommended for preventorium care. These children are supposed to be sent to the new Indian Hospital at Sardis, B.C., and are awaiting the consent of their parents before leaving for the south.

The general health of the remainder of the children is very good, and very little time has been lost by any of the children on account of sickness.

CROPS.

In common with most of the province, the crop yield was rather disappointing this year, due to prolonged rains. A large proportion of the grains were entirely lost, and the potato crop was far below what is necessary for the use of the school. Carrots, cabbage, peas, turnips, and other vegetables were very good.

Livestock

Due to the shortage of the hay crop, we cut down our beef herd by selling most of the young steers and calves. We are doing fairly well with our hogs and chickens, which have shown a good profit during the past year.

LEJAG INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

GENERAL REPORT
for quarter ending June 30th., 1941.

ATTENDANCE.
Attendance has remained constant throughout the quarter, and we still have actually 159 children in the school.

MORALE.
This has remained at a high level, and there is no real reason to complain about the behaviour of the children, who all seem to be quite happy and contented at school. There have been no runaways during the past quarter; it is almost three years since we have had to report runaways.

MANUAL TRAINING.
Both the boys and girls are proceeding along the usual lines in this regard, and the results are satisfactory. The girls do quite a lot of work for the Red Cross.

HEALTH.
The general health of the children has remained good all during the past three months. Only one child had to be sent to hospital for arthritis; but he has now returned and is in good health again.

CROPS.
Prospects for the coming season are excellent, and we are already putting up our first hay crop, which is a large one. Our farm is in excellent shape, and has been highly commended by the Minister for Agriculture, Dr. McDonald, and other officials of his department.

LIVESTOCK.
All of our animals are doing well. The lamb crop for this year amounted to 78 lambs from 48 ewes, which is quite satisfactory. The increase of cattle and pigs is also satisfactory. Our Holstein milk cows are still leading all of the cattle in the district, of all breeds, in milk production and percentage of butter fat.

IMPROVEMENTS.
The ice cooling plant which was installed last winter in place of the ammonia cooling system is working very well and we are quite pleased with it. I believe that this system could be utilised by other schools to their advantage.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith a letter dated the 2nd instant received from Mr. Indian Agent Howe, advising that the Rev. A. R. Simpson, Principal of the Lejac Indian Residential School is employing single male Japanese on the school farm.

As the Department is no doubt aware, public feeling in British Columbia has been running very high in respect to Japanese, who are in the process of being moved back into the interior of the Province. It is not very long since the Canadian Legion protested against the employment of an enemy alien at this school, a problem that disposed of itself by this man running amok and stabbing the Principal and another man, for which he was convicted.

While, as Mr. Howe points out, there is no legal objection to the employment of enemy aliens at such institutions supported by public funds, unless they happen to be within a defence zone, the practice does give rise to very considerable public criticism and, in my opinion, it would be advisable to consider the issuance of instructions to school principals and others, requiring Departmental permission for the employment of such persons. This course would be justified by the fact that at residential schools particularly, these aliens would be in a position to carry out considerable destruction of Government property.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay
Indian Commissioner for B. C.
