Sir:

The attitude of the Indian Department concerning the employment of Japanese on the school farm, as expressed by your communications of the 18th inst., came as a great surprise to me. It is imperative that the Japanese be removed from the defence zones of this province, and the great obstacle in the way of this removal is that the Government does not know where to put these people; therefore, I thought that I was doing the authorities a service by bringing three Japanese here, since we are more than 250 miles inside the defence zone, as defined at present.

You must be aware of the fact that it would be impossible to operate this school without having a farm attached to it. And for the farm we have to have hired labour. Due to prevailing conditions, it is very, very difficult to find farm help; and when one does find them, the wages demanded are beyond our ability to pay. There is no white labour to be had in this area; and the Indians can make from $5.00 to $10.00 per day in the mines and lumber industry, so they are not going to accept farm wages, at least the farm wages that we can afford to pay.

It is daily becoming more difficult to make ends meet, and the 7½ per cent cut that was made in the per capita grant two years ago, does not make things any easier. During the fiscal year just ending, besides supplying the school with all of its milk, butter, eggs, meat, wool, and nearly all of its vegetables, the cash income from our farm amounts to nearly $6,000.00. This constitutes almost 20% of our total cash income, which we cannot afford to lose.

The antecedents of the Japanese men employed here were carefully investigated before they were hired; they have excellent characters, and have belonged to the Catholic Church for a number of years. Also, before I took any action I discussed the matter with the representative of the Provincial Dept. of Agriculture, and other leading citizens of this district, and obtained their approval. I also notified the local Indian Agent two or three weeks before any of these men came here.

In view of all this, I was pleased to learn that the Indian Department had decided to reconsider its decision in this case. I can assure you that in all of my actions as principal of this school, the welfare of the children and of the school is always the prime consideration.

Yours truly,

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.

There is a movement of some of the
neighbouring reserves to have day schools on their
reserves, rather than send their children to this
residential school. The leaders of this movement
are individuals who are hostile to the school.
While I have a certain amount of sympathy for the
idea of day schools, I do not think it suitable for
the Indians of Northern B.C. as yet. Our people are
still nomadic to a great extent and spend a great
part of their time away from their reserves. There is
a great lack of discipline in our Indian families and
the parents will not oblige their children to do
anything they do not want to do. If a child does not
want to attend school, the parents will not take any
action to make them do so. In the Stuart Lake Agency
alone I venture to say that two thirds of the children
are not being educated. Many of the reserves there are
small and remote, and difficult to access. But even in
nearby reserves there are many children who never attend
school. The capacity of this school is limited, and we
have children here from four of the largest agencies in
the Dominion, namely Stuart Lake, Babine, Stikine and
Skeena, for which this is the only Residential School
available. To remedy this situation I would suggest
that either this school be enlarged or other schools
built. Also I think that the provisions of the Indian
Act obliging the attendance of the Indian children at
some school be more rigorously enforced than they are
at present. Many of our children are ten years of age
or more when they are admitted and a large proportion
of these only attend for two or three years, some even
less. Consequently, they do not receive enough education
and training to be of any real use to them.

Dear Mr. Howe:

With regard to the letter which Chief Isadore sent to Ottawa concerning the treatment of children at this school, I wish to make the following observations:

1. The Department already has the facts on the cases cited, except that of the boy who was injured unloading sacks, which is entirely without foundation in fact.

2. As part of their training, the boys help with the work on the farm; but they are never called upon to do anything beyond their strength. All "heavy work" is done by the hired men.

3. The little boys do carry the firewood to the kitchen. But, as this is cut into pieces 12 inches long, and they take only a few pieces at a time, such work is not too much for them. The boiler wood is hauled by the men to the door of the boiler room, where it is piled and then carried into the boiler room as required by the larger boys. Since we usually have about 20 boys on this chore, each one carries about three or four pieces each day.

4. Personally, I am of the opinion that Chief Isadore's motive in writing this letter is a purely selfish one. He has a ten year old girl in his house, the daughter of Harry Paul, who is treated as a veritable slave. I have tried the past two years to prevail upon him to send this girl to school without success. He is afraid that I will try again this fall.

5. The records of the Royal Commission, which came into this area in 1914, show that Chief Isadore was a leader in asking for the establishment of a Residential School here.

6. Investigation will probably show that Chief Isadore wrote this letter without the approval, or even knowledge, of the majority of his band. I would suggest that, before giving credence to such letters, the Department should require that they be signed by two of the Counsellors; or, as in the case of the Stellaco Band, by the Second Chief.

Yours truly,

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.
Principal

GENERAL REPORT

For quarter ending September 30th., 1945.

ATTENDANCE

At the time of writing there are 182 children in school. Although a number of the children who were present during the past school year have not returned we are already 22 over our allotted number of 160. Consequently, we are obliged to refuse admission to any more applicants, except, of course, for those who may be neglected or indigent.

Contrary to our expectations, the Family Allowances did not impede the children from coming back to school. In fact, we had less trouble this year than on any other year in my experience.

MORALE

All of the children are cheerful and happy. Several boys who caused quite a bit of trouble last year did not return, and the others seem to be better off without them.

HEALTH

Apparently, all of the children are in good health, save for a few colds and some severe cases of impetigo. Nearly all of the new children are badly in need of dental care; and many others require tonsillectomies.

LIVESTOCK AND CROPS

Once again an abnormally dry summer has wrought havoc with our crops. Our grain and feed drops were very light, so we will have to purchase considerable quantities of both to see us through the coming winter. The potatoes are also very poor. Since we were able to irrigate the gardens we have good crops of all the staple vegetables.

Due to the depredations of coyotes and wolves we lost quite a few stock, especially lambs; so much so that we have decided to go out of sheep altogether.

PROPERTY

A considerable amount of painting and kalsomining in the hallas and dormitories and digging rooms was done during the summer. Once again we have to face the winter with a building that is almost impossible to heat due to the looseness of windows and doors. For several years we have been trying to get the exterior wood surfaces of the house painted, but have been unable to do so owing to the shortage of labour.

We find that our electrical output is now insufficient for our needs, and suggest that a larger diesel generator be obtained by the Department from the War Assets Corporation. An output of at least 15 kw. would be desirable.

The boiler inspector made certain recommendations regarding our hot water supply which I hope will be accepted, because we are woefully short of hot water on bath days.

Rev. Alex. R. Simpson, O.M.I.
Principal

Dear Sir:

I met a delegation of Indian representatives at Vanderhoof. I desire to place before you the burden of their plea.

GENERAL REPORT

For quarter ending June 30th., 1945.

ATTENDANCE

This has remained quite constant throughout the quarter. Three new children were admitted, and very little time was lost through sickness and hospitalisation. Our daily average for the quarter is 177.7, as compared with 174 for the previous quarter.

MORALE

On the part of the girls, morale has remained at a very high level; but due to some disturbing elements among the boys we have had a little trouble. Two boys ran away just before the end of the year, one of them being brought back the following day.

HEALTH

The health of the children continues to be very good. There have been no epidemics, and very little sickness of any kind. We took five children to the hospital for tonsillectomies. The Dept. had authorised a tonsil clinic for the school, but the surgeon was unable to get away at a suitable time, so we have postponed this clinic until the new school year. The five above children were in extreme need, so we sent them to the hospital.

Farm

The prospects are not very bright for a good crop again this year. The spring was late, and continued dry cold weather does not encourage the growth very much. We are still having labour trouble on the farm.

CLASSWORK

This year two girls passed the Provincial tests for Grade VIII, and will start grade nine next year. Both of these girls are now 16 years old, but application is being made to the Department for permission to allow them to continue their studies.

MANUAL TRAINING

The girls are gaining valuable experience in the work of remaking discarded army clothing over for the use of the children. The boys are following the usual lines of carpentry, smithing, shoe-repairing, gardening, etc.

For sometime past I have been gravely concerned over the lack of school accommodation in this Agency. Now that the national war emergency has been greatly relieved the time is ripe for when something should be done to remedy the situation.

In this connection I am enclosing herewith a list showing the total number of children between the ages of seven and sixteen years of each Band in the Agency and those who are attending school and the number at home uneducated. It will be noted there are 202 children in the latter category.

At the close of the last term there were 151 pupils in attendance at the Lejac Indian Residential School, which includes 29 from the Stikine Agency, 9 from the Babine Agency and 2 from the Vancouver Agency, leaving 141 pupils from the Stuart Lake Agency. The official capacity of the Lejac School is 160 pupils, therefore accommodation has been taxed to the utmost.

Moreover another wing should be added to the Lejac School or day schools should be established on reserves where practicable. Personally, I am in favour of day schools and wish to recommend that immediate steps be taken to construct and operate a day school on the Stony Creek Indian Reserve, 9 miles south of Vanderhoof. A modern school should be built to accommodate 50 pupils, preferably with quarters attached for married teacher whose wife may be available as part-time field matron if desired. A day school on this reserve would relieve the accommodation at Lejac School and make room for 45 children from remote areas where day schools are not practicable. These children would also greatly benefit by the medical supervision provided at the school and manual training and farming instruction which is sorely needed amongst the remote bands.

The Indians as a whole, particularly in remote areas are not favourably disposed to sending their children to residential schools, and a great deal of persuasion and tact would be required in this connection. It may be necessary to invoke the truancy sections of the Indian Act to enforce attendance, but regardless of the methods employed, these underprivileged children will benefit considerably by a period in Lejac Residential School and accommodation should be made available for this purpose.

I had intended applying for a day school at the Necoslie Indian Reserve, Fort St. James, B. C., as well as Stony Creek, but the time being a school at Stony Creek would relieve the congestion at Lejac School for a year or so. If, at the end of this period additional accommodation is still required, plans for a day school at Necoslie may be submitted for consideration.

For the past few years considerable pressure has been brought to bear on this office for day schools by the various Bands, particularly Stony Creek and Necoslie Bands, and I am confident we may be assured of the full co-operation of the Indians in this connection. Absenteeism, which, I understand has been quite a problem with day schools, will be totally eliminated with the payment of Family Allowances. Adequate medical supervision is also available at Stony Creek, which is not available in remote areas, consequently most of these children are in deplorable physical condition. Dear Mr. Howe:

With regard to Mr. Phelan's letter to you of October 4th, concerning certain criticisms expressed by a delegation of Indians from your agency about this school, I wish to make the following observations:

1. "Education is neglected to make the school farm pay." The Department cannot be ignorant of the fact that some of the children do a certain amount of work on the farm, not only in this school but in every other school that I know of. This is supposed to be part of their training. As to making the school farm pay, every cent of revenue from the farm goes into the school funds; without this we could not operate the school. Our annual grant amounts to $29,600, we have 188 children in school, so our per diem grant amounts to 43 cents per child. To feed and clothe a child on 43 cents per day is impossible. If reference is made to my quarterly reports for the past year or so, you will find that I complain of the small number of boys who are old enough to be of assistance in the farm work.

2. "The children learn only to pray and to milk cows." To reply to this specific complaint about milking cows. In this school two boys go to the barn each morning and evening to help with the milking. These boys are changed each week and there are 12 boys on the milkers list; thus each boy has to milk one week out of every six. While milking they miss four evening classes in the whole week. Milking machines are used here, and most of the work is done by two hired men. I know of another school where 21 boys go out to milk each morning and evening. I think that the above complaint is groundless.

Before any steps are taken to change the system of education of the Indians in this area, I think that it would only be fair to ascertain the true opinion of the Indians themselves. These so-called "delegations" are usually self-appointed and do not have any right to pose as representing their people. I would suggest that Indians who have, or have had, or have been, children in this school be asked individually for their opinion as to the type of school they prefer.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Wilson:

I have your letter of September 9th, with regard to the complaints of Councillor Adams Alexis of the Stony Creek Band, relative to conditions at the Lejac Indian Residential School.

The underlying motive behind the complaints, is the Indian's desire for Day Schools on the Reserves. The Department is definitely in favour of Day Schools, and there is no doubt that in the not too distant future, Parliament will provide funds for this purpose. In the meantime, we have to make use of the existing facilities.

Regarding Sanitary conditions. The Lejac School is kept in spotless condition. It is one of the cleanest and most sanitary Public Buildings in B.C. Far more sanitary than most of the White Schools. Adequate medical and hospital facilities are provided at all times.

Of late years, the Department has taken definite and progressive steps towards control of tuberculosis. Provincial x-ray Clinics examine the pupils twice a year. Any pupil showing the slightest sign of tuberculosis is removed to Hospital immediately, away from other contacts. Owing to the fact that this disease is discovered at the School, on or shortly after arrival of new pupils, the parents have the mistaken impression that it is contacted at the School. I have spent many an hour trying to convince them to the contrary.

The time spent by pupils in Manual Labour and religious instruction has been a controversial matter for many years. A Joint Committee of the House and Senate has recently been set up to examine and consider the Indian Act, and I am convinced that many changes will take place, particularly in relation to education, class-room Curriculum, employment of fully qualified Teachers, and establishment of Day schools where practicable.

I have patiently discussed the situation fully with Chiefs and Headmen of the Agency on several occasions, including Adams Alexis, and advised them that they are defeating their own ends by boycotting the Lejac Residential School at this time. They must have patience, Rome was not built in a day.

It is my duty to see that pupils return to School in accordance with Sec.10 (4) of the Indian Act. I do not wish to invoke the Truancy Section of the Act, if the Indians can be persuaded by other means. Anything you can do to help, in the way of advice to your client will be most appreciated.

Schools:

Several visits were made to Lejac Indian Residential School during the quarter. Owing to the admission of several pupils to hospital for tuberculosis and other complaints, the pupilage is down to the official quota.

GENERAL REPORT
For quarter ending December 31st., 1945.

ATTENDANCE
Although, as stated in the report for the previous quarter, we had determined to refuse admission to applicants for this school, it has been very difficult to follow this policy and now we find that we have 190 children now in attendance. Of course, this means that we are somewhat overcrowded, but at least the children are being educated.

A hall or gymnasium is badly needed here. This could be combined in a new building with more dormitory and classroom space.

MORALE
The children are all quite contented. There has not been any attempt at running away from school, as yet. For the Christmas Concert on December 22nd., we had about 160 Indian visitors. Only one out of all these had any criticism to make, and he hardly merits any consideration.

HEALTH
As far as the general health of the children is concerned, this is one of the best years we have had so far, in that there has not been any serious sickness among the children. There have been two or three injuries sustained in playing hockey, but nothing of a serious nature. Since the visits by parents and friends for the Christmas concert, nearly everyone in the house has had a cold, but nothing to worry about.

LIVESTOCK
Due to short crops of last season we are now buying feed for all of the livestock, which adds considerably to our current expenses.

General Remarks.

On his last visit, the boiler inspector made certain recommendations regarding the hot water supply, but, so far, these have not received any consideration by the Department. This condition has been complained of for a number of years past. On bath days for the children there is not half enough hot water.

Due to the fact that the Indians are constantly complaining of the carrying of boiler wood by their children, and the increasing cost and difficulty of obtaining supplies of cord wood for the boilers, I would suggest that the Department consider the question of converting our heating system to an oil-burning one.

I wish to advise that the Rev. A.K. Simpson, Principal of the Lejac Indian Residential School, reported 100 absentee pupils at the opening of the term, September 3rd last. Despite the efforts of the Agency Staff and the assistance of Cpl. Fielder of the local Detachment of the R.C.M.P., there are still approximately 70 truants.

The Indians list a number of grievances, such as the time spent by pupils in manual labour, and religious instruction, and also, their desire for Day Schools, as reasons for keeping the children at home. The antagonism and opposition displayed by the Indians towards the Lejac Residential School is more marked in recent months than at any time since I took over the Agency 8 years ago.

I have patiently discussed the situation with the Chiefs and Headmen of the Bands concerned and advised them that in all probability in the not too distant future, changes will take place, particularly in relation to education and establishment of Day Schools where practicable, and that they are defeating their own ends by their present attitude.

The Stony Creek Band, where there are 40 absentees are particularly adamant, and positively refuse to return the children to school. They recently sent a representative to interview and obtain legal advice from Mr. F.E. Wilson, Barrister at Prince George, B.C. I am enclosing copies of correspondence between Mr. Wilson and myself in this regard. It is gratifying to note that Mr. Wilson gave sound advice and advised his clients to send the children to school.

In view of the determined attitude of the parents I feel that in order to ensure attendance at Lejac Residential School, action should be taken under the Truancy Section of the Indian Act. I have already served written notices on about 15 parents in accordance with Sec. 10, sub-sec. 3 of the Act, but before proceeding to issue summonses, I would like to have the Department's advice and approval.

I would strongly recommend that when the new School Inspector is appointed for B.C., that he meet the Chiefs and Headmen of this Agency to discuss and investigate their complaints at the first opportunity.

A reply by air-mail will be appreciated.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Ottawa, July 26, 1917.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of the March and June quarter returns of attendance from the Stuart Lake Boarding School.

In reply I beg to say that the grant for the March quarter is only being paid for 59 days the pupils were in attendance, viz.: from February 1st to March 31st. The grant due for that quarter amounts to $819.37 and is paid at the rate of $125.00 per capita.

The grant for the June quarter is paid for a full attendance of 41 pupils and amounts to $1383.75.

The grants to all residential schools were increased by $10.00 per capita from the first of April last, for the present fiscal year only and, therefore, the grant to your school for the June quarter is being paid at the rate of $135.00 per capita.

An advance of $500.00 had previously been sent you and there is a balance due for the two above named quarters of $1403.12, a cheque for which amount will be sent you.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa, November 14th, 1933.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of the September quarter return of the Lejac Indian Residential School and it is noted that the maximum number of days for which grant is requested for any pupil is seventy-two (72). It would, therefore, appear that all pupils in residence in June were allowed home for holidays. If this is so, the return has been prepared in the proper manner, as you were informed in official letter of July 12th, last, that, in preparing the September quarter return, the Principal should request grant for the number of days each pupil was in residence during the quarter, plus 43 days' holidays, for which grant is allowed.

If, however, any of the pupils were kept in the school during the whole of the September quarter, the Principal should have requested grant for 92 days for such pupils. You might make inquiries and advise the Department if there were any pupils kept in residence during the full quarter and, if so, you should state their names and register numbers.

The reason for the Department requesting this information is due to the fact that we wish to allow the school all the grant to which they are entitled. I may say that, in preparing the September quarter return, the Principal obtained his average attendance by dividing the aggregate number of days by 72. He should have divided the aggregate attendance by 92. By so doing, of course, the average would only be 106.79, which would mean that the earnings would be less than he requested.

In order to have the information requested in paragraph 2, before finally paying the grant for the September quarter, the Department is only forwarding the Principal a partial payment of $3,000. The balance of grant due will be paid when your reply is received giving the information requested in this letter.

A duplicate copy of this letter is enclosed, which you can hand to the Reverend Principal.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

R. H. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Vanderhoof, B. C.

Reverend Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo, with reference to the March quarter grant of the Fraser Lake Indian Residential School.

Up to the present, we have received an interim appropriation which only permits making absolutely necessary expenditures. Under these circumstances, the Department has been unable to issue cheque for your March quarter grant. Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 29th ultimo, I beg to say that the June quarter return of the Fort George Residential School has been reviewed, and the under payment of $4.25 will be allowed when issuing cheque in payment of the September quarter per capita grant.

The Moose Factory Residential School grant is allowed for 40 pupils, and payment was made for this number (see cheque No. 13592). This information should have been entered on the quarterly return.

At the St. Bernard Indian Residential School, grant was allowed for 85 pupils, and the amount due was included in Central Office cheque No. 3562.

At the McIntosh School grant is provided for 60, and payment was made for this number (see voucher No. 12025).

At the Lejac Residential School grant is provided for 150 and was paid for this number (see cheque No. 10515).

I regret that the number for which grant is allowed at each of the four schools just mentioned was not included on the respective returns. If this information had been given to you, you would have noted that neither over payment nor under payment was made on any of these four schools.

July 7th 1938

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Would it be possible to have the cheque for the quarterly Grant sent direct to the Canadian Bank of Commerce instead of to the School? I have discussed the matter with the manager of the bank and he tells me that there would be no objection as far as the bank is concerned and that they would deposit the cheque to the credit of the school account and notify me of its receipt.

We are situated about forty-five miles from the bank and it is not always convenient to drive that far. The roads are often impassable in winter and as they are only gravelled in patches, travelling is often difficult in summer. It would therefore save us a great deal of trouble if the cheque were sent to the bank.

Yours sincerely,

Rev. W. Byrne-Grant, O.M.I.

Oct. 7th, 1930.

Mr. H.M. Moore,
Indian Agent,
Vanderhoof, B.C.

Dear Mr. Moore:

In view of my departure from the school at the time when the Per Capita Allowance for the past quarter is about due, I think it would be wise to ask the Department to make the Cheque payable to the bank of Commerce, at Vanderhoof instead of to me personally.

There are several advantages in this proposal.

FIRST:- It would protect the bank while the school account is overdrawn.

SECOND:- It would enable the cheque to be deposited to the school account, even if the Principal happened to be absent at the time.

THIRDLY:- It would save a great deal of trouble during the winter months when the trip from the School to Lejac is both difficult and costly.

I would be glad therefore if you would convey this request to the Department.

Yours sincerely,

Signed:- W. Byrne Grant, O.M.I.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES CANADA
Copy sent to Mr. Turgeon

Ottawa,
February 1, 1940.

Dear Father Simpson:

Mr. J. C. Turgeon, M.P. for Cariboo, recently interviewed me and presented very strong reasons why the pupilage at the Lejac Indian Residential School should be increased.

The authorized pupilage at your school for which grant has been provided since April 1, 1935, is 160. However, for the last few months we have been allowing grant for 3 supernumerary pupils making a total of 163 for whom you have been paid. However, we cannot any longer allow supernumerary grant and consequently in future we can only pay for 160 pupils. I would like to be in a position, in view of the arguments presented by Mr. Turgeon, to definitely advise you that your authorized pupilage would be increased but due to present economic conditions it is simply impossible to give any definite assurance whatever regarding any matter that would involve increased expenditure. May I point out that requests for increased pupilage are received almost daily from principals of residential schools throughout the Dominion. However, the funds at our disposal do not permit favourable consideration being given to these requests and consequently I would like to assure you that you are not being treated any differently than the many other residential schools where apparently the management considers that more pupils can and should be accommodated than the authorized pupilage. The only possible solution that I can offer is to reduce your pupilage to the authorized number. This could be done by discharging pupils whose home conditions are satisfactory or those approaching their 16th birthday and who have had the opportunity of some

Rev. A. R. Simpson, O.M.I.,
Principal, Indian Residential School,
Lejac, B. C.
years tuition. In this way it might be possible to provide accommodation for those who have not yet attended school.

Mr. Turgeon also mentioned that he was under the impression that you had stated to him that the Kamloops Residential School was paid a higher rate than you are. In this regard may I say that the per capita rate at both Lejac and Kamloops is exactly the same; namely, $170.00 per annum. Mr. Turgeon also understood that you referred to another school which is being paid at a slightly higher per capita rate than yours. The arrangement with this particular school was made some years ago due to special circumstances which, in the opinion of the Department, still exist.

I can assure you that in the event of funds being provided for an upward revision of the pupilage at Indian residential schools the requirements at Lejac will not be overlooked.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Sir:-

The Local Manager of the Canadian Bank of Commerce spoke to me this morning regarding the matter of having the Quarterly Per-Capita cheque for the Lac Le Jeune Indian Residential School sent directly to the Vanderhoof branch of the Canadian Bank of Commerce. He says that apparently the last cheque for the September quarter went to the Principal of the School. In this connection I would respectfully refer you to my letter of October 14th, 1938 File No. S-2-60, enclosing a copy of a letter from Rev. Father Grant requesting that the quarterly cheque be sent to the bank direct. The school account is apparently overdrawn at the bank and this would protect the bank and would be of advantage to the School in various ways as explained in the Principal's letter.

Your obedient servant,

Jas. H.F. Lacey,
Acting Indian Agent.

July 24th., 1947.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Thank you for your letter of the 8th. inst. I must apologise for having caused so much unnecessary fuss. When the second cheque arrived I had it in my mind that the first one had been for only $5000.00; and, instead of verifying this by looking at my books, I sent in the letter about the alleged shortage.

Upon receiving your letter I checked my books and found that I had been mistaken.

Dear Sir:

In replying to your letter of June 13th., which was signed on your behalf by Mr. Doucett, I wish to point out that in my previous letter I was not asking for grant over and above our authorized pupilage; but my complaint was that the amount of grant received was exactly $200.00 short of what it should be for 175 pupils with a per capita grant of $220.00 per annum.

I had thought that this shortage of exactly $200.00 was probably due to an error in calculation; but it is implied in your letter that it is due to the fact that two pupils were shown in the March Return as having been present for the full quarter, after having been shown as absent in the previous Returns. Even had these children been absent our average for the quarter in question would have been 177.7, which is 2.7 over our authorised pupilage. Therefore, we were even then entitled to our full grant for 175 pupils.

The two pupils, No. 0505 and No. 0506, returned to school on January 7th. Since this was the first day of school in the new term it was not felt necessary to make any deduction in their regard.

Due to our present financial difficulties we can ill afford to let go this shortage of $200.00. We also have present for the summer vacation over forty children, for whom no remuneration is received over that received for the other children who spend these two months at home.

Trusting that this explanation is satisfactory and that a favourable reply will be received in due course, I remain,

Yours truly,

Ottawa, November 28, 1947.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Lejac Indian Residential School,
Province of British Columbia.

The above is a Government-owned school with an authorized pupilage of one hundred and seventy five.

On October 23rd, 1947, the barn at this school was destroyed by fire. We have been in communication with the Indian Agent and also with Indian Commissioner MacKay regarding the matter and we are advised that temporary accommodation has been provided for the live stock during the coming winter. However, with the destruction of the barn and silo, the school management lost 110 tons of hay and alfalfa, 15 tons of grain, milking machine, grinding machine, two sets of harness and assorted implements. Indian Commissioner MacKay states that the cost of the feed that was destroyed by fire is approximately $3,000, and the cost of the equipment $500, or a total loss to the school management of $3,500.

In order to permit the school to continue efficient operation, it will be necessary to replace the feed and equipment at the earliest possible date. This is a special case and Major MacKay considers that we should reimburse the school management to the extent of $3,500.

At the present time we are paying the school an Emergency Grant of $35. If we allow this school an Emergency Grant of $55, for the calendar year 1947 it would mean an extra payment to them of $3,500, as their average
pupilage is one hundred and seventy five.

Funds for this payment are available in the current year's appropriation and I would appreciate it if you would approve the above mentioned extra payment being made.

APPROVED

Director

Oct 12th 1948

Mr. Philip Phelan
Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of Oct. 8th—I am afraid that I did not check the Quarterly Returns carefully enough. Due to pressure of work and the worry of an epidemic of measles I did not check back with the June Report.

The Antoine family returned on Aug. 14th so Paul is eligible for only 47 days. Mary, sewn and Gloria Derrick returned on Sept. 3rd so are eligible for 27 days. Miriam Peter returned Sept 11th. She was absent for a short period before the holidays. Does this make her ineligible for the holiday grant? I had to keep about 50 children here for the holidays which is more than other are asked to do.

I hope the grant is not held up too long. I have to pay interest on an overdraft at the bank. I had to do this six months ago when the Department sent the cheque to Vancouver instead of Vanderhoof. The money arrived a month late. I do not mind paying for my own mistakes but resent paying for the ones of the Department.

Yours truly,

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott,

With reference to the building of a cupola on the Fraser Lake Indian Boarding School, I wrote to Mr. Myles Morley, Inspector of Construction, and asked him to advise me if it would be possible to build this cupola at the present time. He has replied, stating that "it is undesirable to build the cupola at the present time as the weather is so unfavourable, snowing more or less every day and that at night frost is down to between 20 and 35 degrees below zero. He also states that it would be safer and much cheaper to do this work in the spring or summer than at the present time."

In view of Mr. Morley's letter, I beg to recommend that the building of this cupola be postponed for the present.

Sir,

I beg to direct once more your kind attention to the great question of the water supply for this institution. Much has already been written on the subject, so I will limit myself to some remarks.

We pump water from a well 180 feet deep, which gets exhausted after 2 hours of pumping, or, if not exhausted, then gives only muddy water. The pump filling up with sand and mud, has to be taken out for cleaning and the replacing of valves every two months. The winter fortunately has been the mildest known for the last 30 years, but such a work could never be done under a temperature of 30 and 40 below as we have it in ordinary winters. The supply of water is inadequate for domestic purposes. What would I say for fire protection? How could we ever expect to have a garden without possible irrigation? I consider it unwise to re-open the school after the summer holidays without a better supply of water.

There is a spring at the foot of the hill about a mile from the buildings and about 60 feet higher than our roof. We watched this spring all winter. It never froze and the flow never got less. I believe the flow of water, which at present is 1/4 of an inch, could be increased with little work.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

When I took charge of this school in October last I exposed to the Department that the best wholesome food for children is plenty of good milk.

We have secured half a dozen of good milk cows for this purpose and we intend to buy some more.

The stable the boys built with the foreman is too small and inconvenient for the proper care of the stock.

We have bought new teams for the farm, but no accommodation for all this stock.

We need barns to store the feed. Hay left outside in a country like this, of 7 months of snow, loses of its quality. A cellar where we can go in, in winter as well as in summer, is needed for the proper care of the vegetables, or we expose ourselves to have everything frozen in opening up outside cellars with 40 or more below zero, as has happened this year, no matter how much care we took. Dear Sir,

As the Estimates are now being prepared I beg to remind you of the necessity of a barn & stable at the Fraser Lake Industrial School. I feel quite confident that the Department has duly provided for that urgent need but I would further press the necessity of having that structure started early next Summer so that it may be used to store up next Fall's harvest and to shelter their cattle. A good deal of land around the school has been cleared and broken last year; it should yield a good crop this year.

And may I ask you at the same what you think of the old project of piping the spring water from the foot of the hill to the school. Dear Mr. [Name],

Your letter dated March 16th has been received. I should have answered your letter earlier but have been waiting to consult with the Rev. Principal who arrived today, having been away for a few days. He informed me he had already written to the Dept. asking for a barn to house 12 head of cattle and a stable for 6 horses. He admitted they had at present only 3 head of cattle and 4 horses, but is increasing his stock to the above number. I am enclosing rough sketch of floor plan for the above number of cattle. You will observe I have shown stable and barn in the building. Should the Dept. think the accommodation asked for too much, you can shorten same accordingly.

My reason for showing long side of building parallel with front of school is from an economical point of view as the ground rises from it of main building to back of barn by over four feet.

It is necessary to go down at least 3 feet for footings, owing to the grade in this part of the country. It is advisable to make the ground floor stout concrete wall with brick veneer for lay loft. A wooden structure would be useless in this part of the country.

On the plan you will observe I have shown a liquid tank (at the end furthest from the main building and well). Into this tank will empty a six or 4 inch pipe with 2 connections from centre of barn and 2 connections from stable. The overflow from said tank I suggest connecting to drain from well room. As soon as the winter appears to have gone, so let you wish that I get this work done at once? I see the new well is already on the site.

Yours very truly,

Your letter dated March 24th is hand written
with Fairbanks Morse bill for 10 H.P. Engine enclosed.

On receipt of your letter dated November 17th 1922 I consulted with the Engineer here, who is a Certified Engineer with long experience. After comparing engines in various catalogues, I thought it a waste of time to ask for competitive prices for the following reasons:

(1) Fairbanks Morse has only one price.
(2) Already there are 3 Fairbanks Morse engines in use here, and in case of breakage, it is easy to duplicate parts, which is a big consideration in this country so far from a city.
(3) Fairbanks Morse engine is most reliable and guaranteed.
(4) Their prices were lower than those in other catalogues.

I wrote Mr. Mayor Bros. Toronto, asking them to send me a catalogue showing the machinery which the Dept had ordered at the same time. I asked them for a sketch of castors and washers, showing exact position of holes in base, in order to fit the rods in position on the concrete bed (when laying same).

I enclose their reply. They state the catalogue sent by them did not show the machinery specified. However, I was able to borrow a Canadian Laundry Machinery Co. Catalogue from a friend.

I am pleased to say the Machinery is up to specification in every detail.

Mayor Bros. wired me as follows:

January 12th 1923

Let me know if you have high pressure steam 600 or 700 lbs. per square inch Indian School Fraser Lake May 18th

Toronto
I replied as follows:

January 14th, 1923

Have not high pressure steam. We are working to a maximum steam pressure of five pounds.

Morley

Adamstown Train Lake

Vertical tubular boiler fitted with 19-1/2 tubes 20' long safety valve to blow off at 180 lbs with 3½ Herbertty injector strength of plate 55,000 lbs. On arrival of the machinery and being able to see what fittings (shafting etc.) were required, I wired Fairbanks Morse to send 10 H.P. Engine at once.

My one thought was economy together with efficiency.

DAIRYING:

No butter was made during the year, as whole milk is served for breakfast. There is really not enough milk for the children. This school should have more cows than it has at present.

FIRE PROTECTION:

Sir,

I beg to notify you that on my return to headquarters on the 6th I found a letter from Rev Father Coccola, Principal of the Indian School at Fraser Lake also a telegram from Mr Morley, Government building inspector, notifying me that at 2.30 on the morning of the 3rd a mysterious fire had broken out at the school, was subdued in an hour and a half after doing damage to the building amounting to roughly twelve or fourteen hundred dollars.

I went up to the school on the afternoon of the sixth examined the damaged part and made what investigation I could. The fire occurred in a small room near the west end of the building on the main floor. This room had been used as a sacristy to hold vestments etc used in connection with the services held in the large class-room (temporary chapel) in the S.W. corner of the building on the same floor. The doors of the two rooms are opposite—the main hallway dividing them.

The contents of the room were, vestments mostly hanging on the west wall, one box of candles and one box containing duster cloths mostly more or less oily. Both these boxes were on the floor. The candles were melted into a mass by the heat but had not burned. The duster cloths had been in use on the afternoon of the day previous to the fire.

No night watchman has been employed for the last two or three months.

His Lordship Bishop Bunoz passed the door of the room, which was open, at 12.30 A.M. or two hours before the fire was discovered and saw no fire and smelt no burning.

Spontaneous combustion did not cause the fire in my opinion. There were no defects in the electric wiring as I am advised it stood a satisfactory test after the fire. The Principal declares it was impossible for any of the children to reach this room at night from the dormitories. It is almost a certainty that none of the staff were in this room after midnight.

The outside doors are never locked and my opinion is that some one from the outside was prowling about the hallway and either by accident or design threw a lighted match into the box of dusters or among the vestments.

Mr Morley and myself have insisted on a night watchman being put on at once and I have urged upon the Principal the necessity of having all outside doors locked securely at night.

I would suggest a searching enquiry to place responsibility for the fire that protective measures may be taken for the future. Kindly advise in this matter.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

The Secretary

Your obedient servant

INTRODUCTION

Sir:

I have the honor to inform you that in accordance with instructions contained in your letter of April 14th, 1945 I visited the Fraser Lake Industrial School situated near Fort Fraser, B. C. and examined conditions with reference to a possible water supply for the above institution to be used for fire protection and domestic purposes.

PRESENT WATER SUPPLY

The Fraser Lake Industrial School which is a three story brick veneer building 150 ft in length has recently been completed by the Department of Indian Affairs and obtains its present water supply by means of a pump operated by a gasoline engine and having a capacity of 5 U.S. gals. per minute. This pump delivers water from a 4" dia. well, 150 feet in depth to two steel tanks situated in the school buildings. These tanks have a combined capacity of 3000 U.S. gals. and are operated under an air pressure of approximately 40 lbs. per sq. in. This water supply is unsatisfactory for the following reasons.

1) The pump is of too small a capacity to supply sufficient water for the school needs.

2) The diameter of the well casing (4") is too small and the soil through which the well is driven (blue clay) is such that it is impossible to operate the pump for more than 4 hours at a time without exhausting...
the water in the well and causing it to become cloudy and unfit for drinking purposes. When this occurs the pump has to be shut down and water allowed to seep into the well again before the process of refilling the tanks can be resumed.

3) The pump is of too small a capacity to be of any use in the event of fire and the only water supply available in case of emergency is contained in the two tanks whose combined capacity as stated above is 5000 U.S. gals.

POSSIBLE SOURCES FOR ADDITIONAL SUPPLY

The Fraser Lake Industrial School is situated near Fraser Lake and there are but 4 possible means of increasing the present water supply, as follows:

1) By means of an additional well to be driven in the vicinity of the school buildings.

2) By means of springs situated at a distance of approximately ¼ miles from the school.

3) By means of a well driven near the lake shore.

4) By pumping from Fraser Lake.

Of these 4 alternative proposals No.1 should not be considered on account of the formation of the ground the sub-soil of which is blue clay and in view of borings made when the present well was being driven it is doubtful if an adequate supply of water could be obtained by this means.

Proposal No.2 should not be considered in view of the fact that the total flow of the springs amounts to only 2000 U.S. gals. per 24 hours and this amount is not sufficient for the school needs. Moreover these springs are situated at an elevation of
approximately 100 feet above the ground floor of the school and at a distance of ¼ miles away. The transmission of water this distance without the use of a large pipe would consume most of the available head in overcoming friction losses, and sufficient pressure could not be obtained at the hydrants for use in case of fire.

For these reasons combined with others not mentioned in this report I would recommend that proposals No.s 3 and 4 receive consideration and that the installation be carried out as follows:

1) that a test well be driven at a point marked A shown on the accompanying plan and that same be carried down to an elevation of at least 5' below water level in the lake, to ascertain if it is feasible to obtain a sufficient supply of water by seepage, to supply the school needs, without the installation of an intake pipe between the well and the lake. If when the well has been carried down a sufficient depth, water is found to flow freely into same, this well should be enlarged and a pump installed to supply to the school as is described later in this report.

Should it be found however that on account of the nature of the soil water will not flow freely from the lake into the well, I would recommend that this well be abandoned and that a second well 6' x 6' in size be driven on the rocky point shown on the accompanying plan and connected by means of an intake pipe with Fraser Lake.

The construction of this second well and intake pipe will entail considerable expense as it will necessitate drilling in rock and hard pan but this is the only point on Fraser Lake in the
vicinity of the Industrial School where an intake pipe can be placed at a sufficient depth to guard against freezing without incurring undue expenditure, on account of the shallow depth of the lake near the shore.

PROPOSED WATER SUPPLY

The proposed plant which will consist of the following machinery, 1 double acting pump having a capacity of 50 U.S. gals. per minute, operated by a 6 H.P. gasoline engine, will be installed in a pump house situated over a well either at point A or on the rocky peninsula which protrudes into the lake as shown on the accompanying plan.

PUMP HOUSE

The pump house will be constructed of two layers of timber with insulating paper between them and set on concrete foundations.

PIPE LINE

The pipe line from the pump house to the school buildings will be of woodstave construction approximately 1450 feet long and 4" in dia. and buried beneath the ground to a depth of 6 feet to prevent freezing.

HEAD

The total head that the pump will be required to operate against when discharging into the supply tanks amounts to 85 feet, equal to a pressure of 36.8 lbs per sq. in., but sufficient power has been provided to enable the pump to
deliver against a pressure of 100 lbs. per sq. in., which will permit of a supply of 50 U.S. gals. per minute being obtained under pressure at the hydrants in the event of fire.

COST

The total cost of the above installation will amount to $4150.00 including purchase of machinery, installation of pipe, drilling of test well and construction of second well and intake pipe on rocky point if necessary.

RECOMMENDATIONS

In view of the above consideration I would hereby recommend that the proposed water supply be installed as outlined in this report and that the work be undertaken and completed before the end of September, 1923.

REMARKS

The above pumping plant when installed will supply the school with sufficient water for all domestic purposes and will permit of the gardens surrounding the school buildings being properly irrigated. In addition to the above, should an outbreak of fire occur, a supply of 50 U.S. gals. per minute would be available at the hydrants under a pressure of 60 lbs. per sq. in., as soon as the pump could be placed in operation.

Sir:-

Referring to your letter of June 15th, No. 163-1-5, and in the matter of the fire which occurred at the Fraser Lake Indian Industrial School, I have made very careful enquiries and questioned all the parties who were at or near the fire on the morning of the 3rd. of June and I can come to no other conclusion but that the fire was caused by some party who was in the unlighted passage on the morning in question and threw a match either wilfully or by accident in among either the clothing and vestments or the box of oily rags that were in the room. I cannot entertain the idea of spontaneous combustion although Rev. Father Coccolo, Principal of the School maintains that the fire originated from spontaneous combustion from the box of oily rags. I very much regret the unsatisfactory nature of this report but I cannot arrive at any real definite conclusion in the matter. I have suggested to the Principal that all out-side doors should be locked every night and that no person whatever should be allowed to obtain admission to the building without permission from the inside.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Dear Sir,

With reference to the conversation which I had the pleasure of having with you yesterday, and in which you expressed the desire that I make known to you all the needs of this Institution, I beg to state the following.

WATER SYSTEM.

Our most pressing need is for an adequate water system. I do not need to refer to the voluminous correspondence which has passed between you and the school about this water question. May it be sufficient that I cite the words of the expert sent by the Department, who pronounced our water system "a joke". It may be a joke, but the joke is on us, and especially in case of fire this system is absolutely and entirely insufficient, as the fire we had at the beginning of June has shown us, when the water supply gave out so quickly that it would have been impossible to check a more serious fire.

ACCOMODATION FOR WORKMEN.

Our second need is for accommodation for the outside workmen. The men at present are located in all kinds of corners and in places where they ought not to be put. Moreover they occupy rooms which we need for other purposes, as for instance the workroom of the boys. Then again it is not deemed advisable to always have the workmen from the outside mixed with the boys, for several reasons, in which I do not need to go in deeper.

ADEQUATE WORKSHOPS.

Our third need is for adequate workshops. At present there is one workroom which is occupied by workmen, as I have stated in the foregoing paragraphs. This workroom is by far too small for the purpose for which it was made. It gives room enough for the cobblers and others performing some work which does not require much room, but it is absolutely inadequate for the teaching of one of the most important trades for boys, to wit, carpentry. This carpentry is one of the most useful trades which can be taught to the Indian boys, and at present it is impossible to teach it as it ought to be taught, for the lack of space. ---The there is the blacksmithing and horse shoeing, which now have to be taught in a kind of shack, which I had erected out of the school grant, rather than to deprive the boys of the acquiring of this useful trade. ---I would suggest that for economy's sake the necessary workshops be built under the housing accommodation for the outside workmen.

STABLING.

COWS.

Our fourth need is for stabling. A while ago I had a communication from the Department to the effect that Inspector Cairns had made the remark that the children did not get enough milk and butter. I wrote back in the effect that I was willing and ready to buy more milk cows, but that I did not see the possibility of keeping milk cows without having the necessary stabling accommodation for them. I may repeat this again: I am ready to buy all the milk cows that may be needed to give the children all the butter and milk they need, provided the Department furnishes adequate stabling for them. As a matter of fact I have already gone farther than that. I was so sure that the Department would see the justice of my demand and the need of stabling, that I have bought a number of she-stock, some actually milking, others to come in soon. How I am going to manage if the Department does not give stabling for them, I do not know, but I am quite confident that I shall have the help of the Department in this.

HORSES.

Another there is the stabling for horses. You know very well, of course, that the per capita grant is not sufficient to give these children all they need, and that the farm must help out. To run a farm in a successful way, I must have horses. At present there are three teams, one of ponies, one of heavy work horses, and one team of very heavy, pure-bred draft horses. These animals will require stabling during the long winter, and you know we are entirely lacking in stabling facilities for these horses.

OUTSIDE RECREATION ROOMS.

A fifth need is the need of outside recreation rooms. As you know the winters are apt to be very severe, and it may happen that the children can not go and play outside for days, on account of the cold weather and the snow. Then they have to stay and play inside, and the recreation rooms we have now are not fit for this purpose. In the original plans and specifications the floors of the recreation rooms were to have been made out of asphalt. It seems that the Department changed this and that floors of cement had to be put in. The consequence of this is, that the dust in these recreation rooms is unbearable. To give the children the fresh air and the exercise they need, I would suggest the building of two big recreation rooms outside, say 30 feet by 50 feet, one for the boys and one for the girls. These recreation rooms could very well consist of nothing but one wall for a partition and a roof, so as to admit as much sunshine as possible in winter. If the roof were a so-called French roof, this could be used as a hay loft, which would help out considerably. I shall gladly furnish the necessary gymnastum apparatus, so that the children can take exercises in summer and in winter, and that the school may be made more attractive to the children.

SPECIAL REPORT RE FRASER LAKE SCHOOL

Sir:

I beg to submit report of my inspection of the above named Institution.

In company with the Agent, Mr. McAllan and the Principal, Rev. Father Coccola, I went thoroughly over the building. I found a good many things that should be altered or rectified, but am only submitting the most important of these. The two outstanding points are:

1. A totally inadequate supply of domestic water.
2. Toilet accommodation not nearly sufficient.

Both these points are most important from the sanitary point of view, the first one having the additional point of safety from fire, to be considered.

The present supply of water, as you already know, is drawn from a well of such a constitution of soil, and such a depth that it has its source in seepage from Fraser Lake. When water to any extent is pumped from same it runs dry, and they have to wait for it to fill again. The consequence is that the supply is constantly short, and in case of fire the building would undoubtedly be inadequate. The water for drinking and washing purposes, is always full of sediment. Finally I might also point out that between the well and its source, Fraser Lake, is situated the overflow from the sewerage tanks. Looking at the matter, therefore, entirely from an unprofessional point of view, my opinion is that the water supply should be taken from Fraser Lake. Why this was not done in the first instance I cannot conceive, except for the reason I am informed, that for his own convenience, the contractor builder sunk this well. Probably in the making of bricks and concrete, the supply was adequate, nor would sanitary consideration be of importance.

I understand that a report by Mr. Tredcroft has been submitted to you on the matter. I have examined the plans and suggestions, and strongly recommend that this work be undertaken as soon as possible. In fact so seriously do I look on the matter that I am inclined to advise the closing of the school until the said system of supply is rectified. I would like to point out the grave scandal that might arise should an epidemic of typhoid break out, and be attributed to this, possibly falsely. It would also lead to endless trouble among the Indians themselves, and greater difficulty than at present in getting their children sent to school. Again should loss of life occur through fire, uncontrolled through want of water, there might be very unpleasant enquiries.

The Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Regarding point 2, toilet accommodation, I wish to point out that at least twelver (12) more water closets should be installed in the building. There is already room for them in the toilet rooms. I am given to understand that night stools, etc., have to be used now, to supplement the toilet accommodation. This is a dangerous method, but unavoidable as long as the water closets are not of sufficient number.

Minor, though at the same time, important points, that I wish to bring to your attention are as follows:

1. Grease trap
2. Workshops
3. Washing up arrangements in kitchen.

No. 1. The grease trap just outside the kitchen has never been completed. It has now got only an old ill fitting wooden cover. It should have an iron airtight cover. As it is, it is simply a place where flies congregate in millions, and as it adjoins the kitchen windows and entrance, it is impossible to keep food, etc., free from flies.

No. 2. Workshops. There is no place available in the building where the children can receive instruction in any of the trades, such as carpentering, iron work, leather work, etc.

As this part of their training is, to my mind, important, though I am afraid rather neglected as a whole, it is most necessary that some place be provided for this instruction. I should suggest that a wooden building be erected adjacent to the school building for this purpose.

No. 3. The sink and drain board in the kitchen are not much more adequate than would be supplied in a fairly large private home.

The five mentioned and enlarged upon points are outstanding and should be attended to. There are a number of other things that could be, with great advantage, changed or added to, and a number of structural mistakes such as poor lighting in kitchen, bad dormitory supervision accommodation, inadequate storage room, awkward fuel supply system, badly laid concrete flooring in play room, etc., that could be enlarged upon, but that would probably be too costly, and these are not points in which salutation and safety depend.

Probably all these points have already been drawn to your attention. You must excuse me, therefore, if I again repeat them. But I feel, in the interests of the Indians and the Department, not to say the good name of the religious body in charge, that I am only doing my duty by laying them before you.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart.

Two years ago the Fraser Lake Indian Residential School main building was completed, at a cost of $175,000. At the time of erection temporary water supply was installed, and it was hoped to arrange for a gravity system from the hills to the rear of the building. An engineer of the Dominion Water Power Branch has lately reported that this scheme for a permanent supply of water is out of the question and it will be necessary to install, without delay, a water tank and pipe line to connect up with a well at the edge of Fraser Lake, some 400 yards to the front of the building.

Fraser Lake is in such an isolated position, that a permanent and satisfactory water supply system should be provided in the immediate future. Last winter mechanical trouble developed and the school was forced to draw water for domestic purposes and was without any fire protection. In June, last, a fire broke out in the main building and was fortunately brought under control, after a few hundred dollars' worth of damage was done. This occurred at a time when the temporary water system was in order, but it emphasized the necessity of providing a permanent and adequate supply at once.

$10,750 is definitely available in the Appropriation for Indian Education, to provide additional equipment at this school. Mr. R. Moncrieff, a general contractor, P. O. Box 726, Vancouver, B. C., has lately completed the laundry and chapel at this school, on a percentage basis, and is well acquainted with local conditions. Mr. Moncrieff's work for the Department has been most satisfactory and has been completed with considerable despatch. I should be pleased to have your authority to engage him to undertake the construction of the permanent water supply system, on a proven cost plus 10% basis.

The cost will be about $10,000.00.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir:

I have your No. 125/1620 of the first instant, enclosing a letter from the Rev. Principal of the Fraser Lake Indian Residential School to Mr. McAllan, relative to the needs at the institution.

I am pleased to inform you that arrangements have been made with Mr. R. Moncrieff, who is the contractor for the Fraser Lake School, for the installation of a complete new water supply system for this building.

The advisability of providing accommodation for male members of the staff and of building adequate barns and work-shops will not be overlooked, when we are preparing our Estimates for the ensuing fiscal year. I should be grateful if you would advise the Indian agent that an effort will be made to provide funds for the most needed improvements.

Sir:-

Referring to our letter of September 19th, No. 163-1-5, and in the matter of installing a water supply system at Fraser Lake Industrial School, I beg to report as follows for the week ending the 13th instant:

Work was actually started on Friday the 5th with two or three men. On Monday the 8th, the force was increased and now at working eighteen or twenty men; all Indians are employed on the job. In pursuance with the Department's instructions a test hole was attempted at point (B). In the mean time was abandoned as necessitating too much rock excavating both in reservoir and pipe line. A second test hole between (B) and the point (A) on the blue print was sunk to lake level and seepage water encountered but on account of soft nature of ground this was also abandoned and what is now thought to be a final location was made slightly West of the (A) point. The well is now down eight feet showing two feet of water standing at lake level. Rock in place has been encountered and progress is stayed pending arrival of drills and powder. In the meantime the full force is working on the ditch. The well or reservoir is so situated that if a sufficient supply of water is not produced by lake seepage a pipe line to connect with the lake can be laid. I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

You will please find enclosed two tenders for pumping outfit with catalogues, etc. attached.

Fairbanks Morse have the machinery in stock at Vancouver, and the other people can supply on two weeks notice.

I have not reported progress of the work as Mr. MacAllan, I understand, has been doing so weakly. Am almost sure it will be necessary to extend intake pipe about 200 feet on lake side of the pump house, as in no case have we found the rock (which is conglomerate) more than about 5 feet below the surface, or about even with the present water level in the lake. Before Spring the lake will likely be about 2 feet lower than at present.

We will not do anything in connection with the intake until the well is sunk to the required depth by which time the seepage may be sufficient for the supply, and make the intake from the lake (which of course will be the most expensive part of the work) unnecessary.

Sir,

Referring to my report on progress being made on water system at the Indian School at Fraser Lake it will be noted that lake seepage is not at present coming into the reservoir in sufficient quantity to form anything like an adequate supply and it will likely be necessary to connect the reservoir with the lake directly by pipe or seepage bed.

Now I would like to have your close attention to the following:- The reservoir is fifty feet from the water's edge and the foreman on the work, Mr. Skelton and myself have both come to the conclusion that a seepage bed constructed partly of pipes near the reservoir and entirely of rock gravel and sand on the lake end would be better than running a pipe all the way. The bed would be laid in a ditch dug as deeply as it was possible or necessary to go and at least three feet wide at the bottom and even if not satisfactory the end of the pipe could at any time be uncovered and continued out into the lake. The reason against taking the water supply in wholly by open pipes is that the lake being shallow at this point it is often very riley in windy weather. Kindly wire me your decision on this matter as time is a very important matter now.

I have the honour to be, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir,-

Referring again to your letter of the 19th Sept No 163-1-5 and in the matter of installing a water system at the Fraser Lake Industrial School I beg to report progress on the work for the week ended Oct 20th as follows,-

Ditch for pipe line completed from tanks in School to reservoir near lake except under railroad track. Pipe laid from tanks to point of first inspection joint and work on pipes temporarily held up pending arrival of joints.

Work on reservoir is progressing satisfactorily the rock is now being blasted and removed but unless water bearing crevices are struck in the next four feet it will be necessary to connect the reservoir with the lake as the seepage is not sufficient. The bottom of the reservoir is now down four or five feet below lake level.

Eight or ten men were paid off on Saturday night and the force reduced to just enough for double shift crews on the reservoir and two men getting the pipes etc ready to lay.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

The ditch from the tanks in boiler room to reservoir at lake completed. Pipe laid from tanks into reservoir. Sir:

Replying again to your letter of September 19th, No. 163-1-5 in the matter of installing the water system at the Fraser Lake Industrial School, I beg to report progress of the work in addition to that already reported.

Since last writing the reservoir has been cemented with the exception of the top slab and the pump house is being erected. The ditch is all filled in from the school to the reservoir as we were afraid of the thrown out ground freezing when it would have been very difficult to have moved it as in some places the ditch had to excavated to a depth of nine feet. The seepage bed is now completed right to the water's edge at a depth at the reservoir of six feet below the lake level and at the lake level of five feet. However only a small amount of seepage was encountered as the strata proved to be solid blue clay so that it will be necessary to run the pipe line for some distance in the water to connect with the seepage bed. The flow of water in the reservoir is now, I estimate at easily 300 gallons per hour and the seepage is coming from such a depth that it cannot I think be interferred with by the freeze up during the winter. However it was felt that to get an adequate supply sufficient for all emergencies it would be better to connect the lake directly with the seepage bed and the reservoir. It is going to prove a difficult matter to get the pipe in the lake down to the necessary depth. We will probably have to wait until the lake freezes over and complete the ditch from the ice and connect the pipe on the ice and roll it into position.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

REPORT

re
Proposed Pumping Plant, Fraser Lake Industrial School.

Sir:

With reference to correspondence regarding pumping machinery for the Fraser Lake Industrial School, which was recently forwarded to me for examination, I wish to state that I have examined the tenders submitted very carefully, and beg to report to you as follows:

Whereas my previous report recommended the installation of one pump to supply 50 U.S. gallons per minute, the tenders submitted are for two pumps, each to have a capacity of 50 U.S. gallons per minute, to be operated by a six H.P. engine, as per the quotations enclosed.

The sketch which accompanied the correspondence, together with the tenders submitted, would indicate that these pumps are not meant to be operated together, but only one at a time, in view of the fact that a six H.P. engine was apparently specified, and I would strongly recommend that, if it is the intention of the Department to install two pumps in place of the one originally recommended, that the power of the engine supplied be raised from six H.P. to ten H.P. in order to allow both these pumps being operated.
at the same time. The extra cost of making this change to supply the additional four H.P. would amount to $318.00, and would be more than justified in view of the fact that the available water supply would be doubled.

In the event of the above alterations being approved of by the Department, I would recommend that the tender of the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Company be accepted as follows:

Two 5½" x 6" Duplex Power Pumps, brass fitted, capacity, 50 U.S. gallons per minute against a working pressure of 150 pounds per square inch at 40 R.P.M. $562.00

One ten H.P. Z Type gasoline engine, hopper cooled, with full equipment and two pulleys for driving 5½" x 6" pumps 608.00

Fittings for pumps as shown in tender (subject to slight alterations depending on method of installation) 120.50

Total $1290.50

Certain alterations in the method of installing the machinery from that shown by the sketch which accompanied the tender would appear to me to be desirable in order to minimize transmission losses.

For instance, the sketch forwarded to me shows the pumps being driven off a countershaft. This is not necessary, as the Z type engine it is proposed to supply has two fly wheels and the pumps can be belted to them direct, one on each side, by means of pulleys 16" in diameter, having a 10" face. This method would permit of both pumps being operated at once or one at a time and would be a neater and more efficient installation.

The above machinery if properly installed, as shown in the accompanying plan, will deliver 100 U.S. gallons per minute to the present storage tanks, which have a capacity of 1500 U.S. gallons, and provided the air pressure in these tanks is maintained at the proper figure (50 pounds per square inch) any hydrant equipped with a 3/4" nozzle and situated on the ground floor of the school will, in the event of fire, be able to
deliver approximately 90 U.S. gallons per minute under a pressure of 45 pounds per square inch, and this supply can be continued as long as the pumps are maintained in operation.

The discharge pipe from the pump house to the storage tanks should be not less than 4" in diameter, and capable of withstanding a pressure of 125 pounds per square inch; and one check valve and one automatic safety valve should be incorporated in the system, and placed close to, but outside, the pump house. This safety valve should be adjusted so that it will commence to discharge water at a rate of not less than 100 U.S. gallons per minute when the pressure in the system reaches 110 pounds per square inch, that being the maximum pressure against which the pumps will be required to operate, provided that the present storage tanks are used and the pressure in them is maintained at not more than 50 pounds per square inch. Care should be taken to place the check valve nearer to the pump house than the safety valve, in order to ensure the proper operation of the latter; and for this purpose I would recommend the installation of the following fittings:

One standard 4" diameter check valve;
One automatic safety valve, adjusted to operate at a pressure of 110 pounds per square inch, and having an area of free discharge when open of not less than 1 square inch.

Your obedient servant,

Acting Division Engineer.
