Memorandum: Mr. Scott.

Tenders have been received from the following firms for the furnishing of an engine and pumps and other fittings for the completion of the water supply system for the Fraser Lake Indian Boarding School, in accordance with the plans and specifications prepared by the Dominion Water Power Branch.

Modern Air-Conditioning Corp., Ltd. . . . . . $1,202.00
Canadian Fairbanks Morse Co. . . . . . . . . . . . . 1,038.50

The above mentioned tenders were submitted to the District Engineer at Vancouver for a report as both firms had advised that a 10 H.P. engine should be installed instead of a 6 H.P. as mentioned in the specifications. A report from Mr. Tradcroft is now on file and recommends that the order be placed with the Canadian Fairbanks Morse Co., which would amount to $1,290.50. The increase in price is due to the fact that the furnishing of a 10 H.P. engine is being considered instead of a 6 H.P. This Company is ready to make delivery of this machinery at once, whereas the other firm cannot deliver for two weeks.

I would recommend that the tender of Canadian Fairbanks Morse Co. be accepted and that the Contractor in charge be requested to place an order at once for the machinery so that this system may be delivered as early as possible. I may add that Inspector Pragnell has also suggested that the capacity of the engine be increased from a 6 H.P. to 10 H.P. one as previously mentioned in the Engineer's report.

Dear Mr. Orr,

In reply to yours of the last inst. re water tank at Fraser Lake School, I have looked into this matter and do not think it would be practical to put tanks in the attic. I think the best plan would be to put up a wood stave tank and house it in. During the very cold weather it could be heated by a stove, and with the house over the tank there would be no trouble from shrinkage in the upper end of the staves in the summer which is often the case because of the tank not being kept full.

The wooden tanks give good satisfaction on the railroad in this locality. Father Coccolo would like to have the tank located about 700 feet back of the school, which is about the highest point on the farm. His idea for having it there is so that it can be used for irrigation purposes. Of course the tank could be placed nearer the building and the water piped to the top of the hill; but by placing it on the hill it could be built about 20 feet lower and make a considerable saving on first cost and also on heating. If you decide to place it on the hill it would be well to get the pipe in as soon as possible, because it is very expensive excavating clay (such as they have on the school farm) after it freezes.

Will be very pleased to give you any further information regarding local conditions, etc.

Yours very truly,

Sir:

Referring again to your letter of September 19th, No. 103-1-5 regarding the water system being installed at the Fraser Lake Industrial School, I beg to report additional progress as follows:

Since writing on December 6th, the pipe line from the reservoir at the lake shore to the site of the elevated tank is all laid and completed and the trench filled in. All of the foundation blocks for the elevated tank are completed and work on the superstructure will commence right away.

The pump house is all completed with the exception of the top slab of concrete which is now being laid. The pumps and engines are on the ground and will be in place and water available in the engine room tanks in two weeks time.

The pipes from the seepage bed out in the lake will be the last piece of work done to enable the lake to fall to its very lowest level.

Cold weather has hampered the work on the concrete parts of the elevated tank very much but it is a source of satisfaction to know that the diton was all done and completed before the cold weather set in.

The temperature has ranged between zero and 40 below for ten days but it has now moderated, trusting that this progress will be considered satisfactory.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,
